episodes.description: In this episode -- and Wes explore different ports and protocols used for communication in modern computer networks. They look at protocols like SSH, DNS, FTP.....etc and their associated ports.
episodes.title: Ports and Protocols
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:01.250
Welcome to ITPRO TV.

2
00:00:01.250 --> 00:00:05.988
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:05.988 --> 00:00:08.169
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.169 --> 00:00:12.749
>> You're watching ITPRO TV.
>> Hello,

5
00:00:12.749 --> 00:00:15.992
welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPRO TV.

6
00:00:15.992 --> 00:00:17.460
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

7
00:00:17.460 --> 00:00:21.540
And today we're doing our
accelerated Comp TIA Network Plus.

8
00:00:21.540 --> 00:00:25.580
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna be focusing in on ports and

9
00:00:25.580 --> 00:00:26.590
protocols.

10
00:00:26.590 --> 00:00:30.920
And here to help us navigate [LAUGH]
our way to this myriad of acronyms and

11
00:00:30.920 --> 00:00:33.790
port numbers is none
other than Mr Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:33.790 --> 00:00:34.700
Welcome, Wes.
>> Hey,

13
00:00:34.700 --> 00:00:36.070
thanks for having me, Mike, that's right.

14
00:00:36.070 --> 00:00:39.740
We're gonna be feeding you guys some
alphabet soup here really, really quick.

15
00:00:39.740 --> 00:00:42.150
But we're gonna hopefully
help you to find, or

16
00:00:42.150 --> 00:00:46.350
at least eat that alphabet soup too and
understand what we are talking about.

17
00:00:46.350 --> 00:00:48.680
Remember, when we talk about a protocol,
what do we mean?

18
00:00:48.680 --> 00:00:51.280
Well, we mean a structured set
of rules for communications.

19
00:00:51.280 --> 00:00:52.840
Remember, that two end points,

20
00:00:52.840 --> 00:00:55.820
if they are going to communicate,
they have to be sharing the same protocol.

21
00:00:55.820 --> 00:00:57.200
It's kind of like language.

22
00:00:57.200 --> 00:01:01.100
I don't speak Spanish, I would love to
learn Spanish, but if somebody's speaking

23
00:01:01.100 --> 00:01:03.652
in Spanish, and I speak in English, we're
not gonna have a lot of communication

24
00:01:03.652 --> 00:01:06.630
[LAUGH] between us versus somebody
that speaks Spanish, right?

25
00:01:06.630 --> 00:01:10.850
Or to people that speak English, keep in
mind, that they can have a communications.

26
00:01:10.850 --> 00:01:13.710
Well, it's kinda interesting,
your networks are the same way, right?

27
00:01:13.710 --> 00:01:15.550
Think of a protocol as a language, right?

28
00:01:15.550 --> 00:01:18.600
And every language has
a set of structured rules

29
00:01:18.600 --> 00:01:21.130
on how they define how you
communicate with that language.

30
00:01:21.130 --> 00:01:23.010
And protocols are the same way.

31
00:01:23.010 --> 00:01:25.040
Now, when it comes to protocols,
all right,

32
00:01:25.040 --> 00:01:29.720
understand that we have services
that rely on those protocols, right?

33
00:01:29.720 --> 00:01:33.320
We have all kinds of things going on,
we have name resolution services,

34
00:01:33.320 --> 00:01:37.250
we've got file protocols that allow us
to access files across the network.

35
00:01:37.250 --> 00:01:42.170
We've got email protocols that will
allow us to send and receive emails.

36
00:01:42.170 --> 00:01:46.200
Now, understand as well that
each one of those protocols can

37
00:01:46.200 --> 00:01:47.900
use a different service type, right?

38
00:01:47.900 --> 00:01:49.230
We called them protocol types.

39
00:01:49.230 --> 00:01:52.080
And one of the big ones we need to
understand is something known as

40
00:01:52.080 --> 00:01:53.750
transmission control protocol.

41
00:01:53.750 --> 00:01:57.400
Now, I want you to understand that
TCP Transmission Control Protocol,

42
00:01:57.400 --> 00:01:59.790
it is a connection oriented service.

43
00:01:59.790 --> 00:02:03.560
Now, it has some overhead,
because of the fact that it brings up,

44
00:02:03.560 --> 00:02:05.340
it maintains the communication,

45
00:02:05.340 --> 00:02:09.520
tears that communication down, but it
also goes a little bit farther than that.

46
00:02:09.520 --> 00:02:13.000
What it does it takes a larger
amount of data and it breaks it up.

47
00:02:13.000 --> 00:02:14.600
It's called segmentation.

48
00:02:14.600 --> 00:02:16.630
And then,
it also does what's known as sequencing.

49
00:02:16.630 --> 00:02:19.193
In fact we've got a little diagram here,
if you look,

50
00:02:19.193 --> 00:02:22.929
one of the things that you can keep in
mind that transmission control protocol,

51
00:02:22.929 --> 00:02:26.801
if you're sending a package, or packet
in this case from source to destination.

52
00:02:26.801 --> 00:02:30.876
It'll take your information and it'll
break it down into more manageable parts,

53
00:02:30.876 --> 00:02:35.006
and what it'll do is it'll sequentially
number these, each one of these packets,

54
00:02:35.006 --> 00:02:36.990
or segments if you will.

55
00:02:36.990 --> 00:02:39.600
Then, what it does is on the recipient and
the destination.

56
00:02:39.600 --> 00:02:40.100
And remember,

57
00:02:40.100 --> 00:02:43.570
the transmission control protocol
is monitoring this the whole time.

58
00:02:43.570 --> 00:02:47.430
If one of these packets, notice we have
one, two, three, and, well, I don't know

59
00:02:47.430 --> 00:02:49.570
what happened to four, went out there too.
>> I think it's missing.

60
00:02:49.570 --> 00:02:51.070
>> That's right, exactly [LAUGH].

61
00:02:51.070 --> 00:02:54.030
What would happen is that
the destination will call and

62
00:02:54.030 --> 00:02:57.260
say, hey, we've got a missing segment
here, we have a missing segment four,

63
00:02:57.260 --> 00:02:58.400
I don't know what happened there.

64
00:02:58.400 --> 00:02:59.940
Can you resend it?

65
00:02:59.940 --> 00:03:02.740
And then, they call back to the source and
the source says, yeah, absolutely,

66
00:03:02.740 --> 00:03:06.730
here's segment four, and
then the communication starts up again.

67
00:03:06.730 --> 00:03:11.350
So, again transmission control protocol,
connection orientated reliable service.

68
00:03:11.350 --> 00:03:13.080
Maintains the communication,

69
00:03:13.080 --> 00:03:17.900
make sure that that information gets
to the end point in a reliable manner.

70
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:22.120
And that is opposite to what's known
as the User Datagram Protocol.

71
00:03:22.120 --> 00:03:25.940
A lot less going on here [LAUGH]
in this demonstration, right?

72
00:03:25.940 --> 00:03:29.590
User Datagram Protocol,
what it allows you to do is,

73
00:03:29.590 --> 00:03:32.400
it allows you to send information
potentially a little bit faster,

74
00:03:32.400 --> 00:03:34.090
because it doesn't have the overhead.

75
00:03:34.090 --> 00:03:37.570
But one of the things that it lacks
is that connection oriented service.

76
00:03:37.570 --> 00:03:39.200
It's kind of like a best effort delivery.

77
00:03:39.200 --> 00:03:42.698
Keep in mind that transmission control
protocols like getting delivery

78
00:03:42.698 --> 00:03:44.886
confirmation on your
snail mail versus UDP.

79
00:03:44.886 --> 00:03:48.268
Which is just kind of like putting it in
the blue mailbox and walking away from it,

80
00:03:48.268 --> 00:03:50.457
and just hoping it gets to
the carriers network, and

81
00:03:50.457 --> 00:03:52.770
hopefully to the destination, right?

82
00:03:52.770 --> 00:03:55.640
So, each of these have their utilizations,
right?

83
00:03:55.640 --> 00:03:56.910
Transmission control protocol,

84
00:03:56.910 --> 00:03:59.920
when I need to make sure that
the data is reliably delivered.

85
00:03:59.920 --> 00:04:04.860
UDP, well, when I need to get something
there maybe a little bit faster, and

86
00:04:04.860 --> 00:04:08.710
it can't really tolerate things like slow
delivery, because of the overhead that

87
00:04:08.710 --> 00:04:11.320
transmission control protocol has.
>> All right, Wes,

88
00:04:11.320 --> 00:04:12.250
[LAUGH] we got a couple of them.

89
00:04:12.250 --> 00:04:13.800
Are there any more that
we have to worry about?

90
00:04:13.800 --> 00:04:14.940
>> There's one that is

91
00:04:14.940 --> 00:04:18.570
kind of interesting, because it's not
really connection oriented protocol, but

92
00:04:18.570 --> 00:04:21.490
it does monitor things like diagnostics.

93
00:04:21.490 --> 00:04:26.884
We have what's known as the Internet
Control Message Protocol, ICMP.

94
00:04:26.884 --> 00:04:30.990
An ICMP is used by a lot of different
utility software that we have.

95
00:04:30.990 --> 00:04:34.700
For instance, as we move into our
troubleshooting tools we're gonna talk

96
00:04:34.700 --> 00:04:37.890
about utilities like Ping,
Packet Internet Groper,

97
00:04:37.890 --> 00:04:41.180
Trace RT, or Trace Route if you're
in the Nicks Bay Systems, right?

98
00:04:41.180 --> 00:04:46.200
And what ICMP does is it allows
you to do things like monitor

99
00:04:46.200 --> 00:04:50.700
the flow of the communications, slow down
the flow of those communications, right?

100
00:04:50.700 --> 00:04:54.100
If I'm sending information from my
computer to Mike's computer here, and

101
00:04:54.100 --> 00:04:56.250
his network adapter, for whatever reason.

102
00:04:56.250 --> 00:05:00.620
Maybe his computer's trying to process
that information and it starts saying,

103
00:05:00.620 --> 00:05:03.850
hey, wait a second, you need to stop,
I'm gonna start losing packets,

104
00:05:03.850 --> 00:05:07.300
if you don't slow down, or
speed up, I'm waiting a while here.

105
00:05:07.300 --> 00:05:09.710
So, Internet Control Message Protocol
is about.

106
00:05:09.710 --> 00:05:13.010
Things like Diagnostics controlling
the flow of communications and

107
00:05:13.010 --> 00:05:15.710
we have different utilities
that also use them.

108
00:05:15.710 --> 00:05:18.155
There's another one that is
completely connectionless it's not

109
00:05:18.155 --> 00:05:22.700
connection-oriented at all, and
that is a very important protocol type and

110
00:05:22.700 --> 00:05:25.010
that's called IP that's
the Internet Protocol.

111
00:05:25.010 --> 00:05:28.696
We're gonna talk pretty extensively
in other episodes About IP, but

112
00:05:28.696 --> 00:05:32.050
just know that it's
connection-less service, right?

113
00:05:32.050 --> 00:05:36.480
We use things if we need connection
services with things like addressing,

114
00:05:36.480 --> 00:05:41.270
that's why we stack transmission control
protocol, on top of things like IP, and

115
00:05:41.270 --> 00:05:43.980
then in fact, I guess,
it would be the other way around, right?

116
00:05:43.980 --> 00:05:46.990
IP is going to piggyback off of
transmission control protocol.

117
00:05:46.990 --> 00:05:49.600
And you'll learn more about that
when we talk about the OSI model.

118
00:05:49.600 --> 00:05:52.640
And these are some of the protocol
types that we need to know that

119
00:05:52.640 --> 00:05:56.830
all protocols are going to use
when we talk about communications.

120
00:05:56.830 --> 00:05:57.550
>> All right, very good.

121
00:05:57.550 --> 00:05:59.560
So, we got our different protocol types.

122
00:05:59.560 --> 00:06:02.730
Well, we can classify our protocols
are either connectionless, or

123
00:06:02.730 --> 00:06:04.590
connection oriented.

124
00:06:04.590 --> 00:06:07.120
Next, I guess, we need to start talking
about some of the protocols we need to

125
00:06:07.120 --> 00:06:08.810
know for this exam.
>> That's right.

126
00:06:08.810 --> 00:06:10.730
So, when we talk about protocols,

127
00:06:10.730 --> 00:06:15.219
understand that some of these we're gonna
talk more in depth, in other episodes.

128
00:06:15.219 --> 00:06:18.298
At this point it's just understand
what the protocol is and

129
00:06:18.298 --> 00:06:21.070
he port number that's
associated with them.

130
00:06:21.070 --> 00:06:27.850
Remember your port, how many possibilities
of ports you have right 0 to 65,535.

131
00:06:27.850 --> 00:06:31.760
They're broken down into three categories
what's known as the well known ports,

132
00:06:31.760 --> 00:06:33.550
the registered ports, and then dynamic, or

133
00:06:33.550 --> 00:06:37.110
private ports depending on
who's material you're reading.

134
00:06:37.110 --> 00:06:40.770
When we talk about well known ports,
these are assigned to common services.

135
00:06:40.770 --> 00:06:44.667
In fact, every one of the common services
pretty much close, there's a couple

136
00:06:44.667 --> 00:06:48.584
registered services that we'll talk about,
and that's from 0 to 1023.

137
00:06:48.584 --> 00:06:51.290
Remember that your registered port range,
right?

138
00:06:51.290 --> 00:06:55.658
These are for things like software and
applications that are kinda

139
00:06:55.658 --> 00:07:00.579
recommendations if you will, and
that is from 1024 to 49,151.

140
00:07:00.579 --> 00:07:06.560
[LAUGH] The last port
ranges 49,152 to 65,535,

141
00:07:06.560 --> 00:07:10.394
and these are used by your computers.

142
00:07:10.394 --> 00:07:11.976
Mike's computer is using them right now.

143
00:07:11.976 --> 00:07:13.590
I'm using them right now.

144
00:07:13.590 --> 00:07:17.640
They basically identify the end point
in a temporary communication and

145
00:07:17.640 --> 00:07:20.980
once the session is done,
communication is no longer used.

146
00:07:20.980 --> 00:07:25.930
They go back over into that pool and your
computer will reuse them as needed for

147
00:07:25.930 --> 00:07:27.920
additional communications.

148
00:07:27.920 --> 00:07:31.780
So, let's look at some protocols and
the ports that are associated with them.

149
00:07:31.780 --> 00:07:34.970
One of the first ones I want to talk
about here, I've got on the slide and

150
00:07:34.970 --> 00:07:36.790
that's known as DNS.

151
00:07:36.790 --> 00:07:40.460
Remember, domain name
system takes your FQDNs,

152
00:07:40.460 --> 00:07:44.818
your fully qualified domain names and
maps them to IP addresses.

153
00:07:44.818 --> 00:07:50.650
That is gonna use UDP port 53 if you're
talking about simple client queries,

154
00:07:50.650 --> 00:07:51.267
right?

155
00:07:51.267 --> 00:07:56.190
Then it also has a transmission control
protocol, or a TCP oriented port too,

156
00:07:56.190 --> 00:07:57.768
which is also port 53.

157
00:07:57.768 --> 00:08:01.388
But that's when two servers are
communicating between them, and you'll go

158
00:08:01.388 --> 00:08:05.470
on as more advanced, trying to learn
a little bit more about that side of it.

159
00:08:05.470 --> 00:08:11.263
So again, remember, domain name systems,
DNS is going to be board 53.

160
00:08:11.263 --> 00:08:12.730
All right.

161
00:08:12.730 --> 00:08:17.470
Now, Mike, I went ahead, we've got a list
of them here, different email protocols,

162
00:08:17.470 --> 00:08:19.530
and I was talking to Mike,
I was like, hey, let's go ahead and

163
00:08:19.530 --> 00:08:21.410
put these all in one list.

164
00:08:21.410 --> 00:08:23.350
We're gonna talk about
the very first one here,

165
00:08:23.350 --> 00:08:26.250
that's SMTP,
simple mail transfer protocol.

166
00:08:26.250 --> 00:08:29.280
Keep in mind, this is for
sending or forwarding email and

167
00:08:29.280 --> 00:08:35.200
that does mean from an SMTP client
as well as between servers too.

168
00:08:35.200 --> 00:08:39.250
Understand that it uses port 25.

169
00:08:39.250 --> 00:08:42.530
We also have an oldie, [LAUGH] as well,

170
00:08:42.530 --> 00:08:45.792
POPv3, post office protocol version three,
notice the arrow here.

171
00:08:45.792 --> 00:08:51.340
Remember that this is for receiving email,
retrieving email off of an email server.

172
00:08:51.340 --> 00:08:55.180
One of the limitations was that when you
would retrieve that email off the server

173
00:08:55.180 --> 00:08:57.610
keep in mind it would erase
your email from the server.

174
00:08:57.610 --> 00:09:00.500
That's something that we're
not really used to today.

175
00:09:00.500 --> 00:09:04.140
Cuz more commonly we connect
to things like Gmail,

176
00:09:04.140 --> 00:09:08.240
we connect to things like Outlook,
right, Office 365, if you will.

177
00:09:08.240 --> 00:09:13.540
And we manage our emails up on their
servers, they handle it, right?

178
00:09:13.540 --> 00:09:17.570
And that's where another protocol comes
in, but I should probably mention the port

179
00:09:17.570 --> 00:09:19.228
here, since it's part of the title, right?
>> Yep.

180
00:09:19.228 --> 00:09:21.290
>> [LAUGH] Post office protocol

181
00:09:21.290 --> 00:09:25.080
version three is gonna be port 110,
and again, retrieving email.

182
00:09:25.080 --> 00:09:28.980
Now the one that I was talking
about was the internet message,

183
00:09:28.980 --> 00:09:30.680
access protocol, right?

184
00:09:30.680 --> 00:09:31.410
IMAP, right?

185
00:09:31.410 --> 00:09:35.241
When we look at the internet mail or
message access protocol.

186
00:09:35.241 --> 00:09:38.291
This is where you can actually
connect to an IMAP server and

187
00:09:38.291 --> 00:09:41.150
you can manage your emails
right on the server.

188
00:09:41.150 --> 00:09:44.580
You can browse through them,
browse through your emails.

189
00:09:44.580 --> 00:09:45.630
You can create folders.

190
00:09:45.630 --> 00:09:46.750
You can group them together.

191
00:09:46.750 --> 00:09:49.850
And this is what we
commonly use a lot today

192
00:09:49.850 --> 00:09:52.440
if you're using something like Gmail or
something like Outlook.

193
00:09:52.440 --> 00:09:54.075
And again, it's up in the cloud there.

194
00:09:54.075 --> 00:09:59.326
Now I do want you to understand that is
going to be port 143, yeah, port 143.

195
00:09:59.326 --> 00:10:03.063
And I do want to make mention on
exam alert here real quick because

196
00:10:03.063 --> 00:10:05.899
there are a couple of these
ports that look like,

197
00:10:05.899 --> 00:10:09.780
if you're not careful on
the exam you can get them wrong.

198
00:10:09.780 --> 00:10:14.130
Do not confuse port 443 and port 143.

199
00:10:14.130 --> 00:10:17.270
We will get to HTTP coming up, but

200
00:10:17.270 --> 00:10:22.570
I want you to remember HTTPS
is what uses port 443,

201
00:10:22.570 --> 00:10:26.330
but your Internet Message
access protocol uses port 143.

202
00:10:26.330 --> 00:10:27.760
Those ones are always easy.

203
00:10:27.760 --> 00:10:31.190
Absolutely on the exam you
might tend to get them wrong.

204
00:10:31.190 --> 00:10:33.270
But hopefully you will get them right.

205
00:10:34.580 --> 00:10:36.680
Next one we have is
what's known as Telnet.

206
00:10:36.680 --> 00:10:40.270
Telnet is an oldie but goodie,
it's been around for a long time.

207
00:10:40.270 --> 00:10:43.077
Now remember that there
are limitations to Telnet.

208
00:10:43.077 --> 00:10:45.638
One of the problems,
I guess not a limitation but

209
00:10:45.638 --> 00:10:48.699
one of the problems with Telnet
is that it allows a terminal

210
00:10:48.699 --> 00:10:51.843
emulation software that allows
you to make a remote logon.

211
00:10:51.843 --> 00:10:54.970
Problem with it is it is
a clear text protocol.

212
00:10:54.970 --> 00:10:57.900
Because it's a clear text protocol or
plain text protocol

213
00:10:57.900 --> 00:11:01.140
that means if Mike I'm gonna throw
the black hat on him real quick.

214
00:11:01.140 --> 00:11:04.380
If Mike's out there and
he is doing some packet capturing, right?

215
00:11:04.380 --> 00:11:05.797
Doing some sniffing on the network.

216
00:11:05.797 --> 00:11:08.778
And he just happens to
catch my log on session or

217
00:11:08.778 --> 00:11:12.532
really anything that's going
on with my Telnet session.

218
00:11:12.532 --> 00:11:16.110
He can rebuild that communication, and
he can see exactly what's going on.

219
00:11:16.110 --> 00:11:20.884
Again, it isn't encrypted, which is what
brings me to our next protocol coming up.

220
00:11:20.884 --> 00:11:23.731
Remember that Telnet,
Telnet operates over port 23.

221
00:11:23.731 --> 00:11:27.610
So know that for the exam.

222
00:11:27.610 --> 00:11:31.938
Now, one of the things that we used to
make remote log ons a little bit more so

223
00:11:31.938 --> 00:11:35.337
today over Telnet is what's known as SSH,
Secure Shell.

00:23:41.880 --> 00:23:44.674
Well, let's go ahead and stay with our
voice over IP communications, right?

453
00:23:44.674 --> 00:23:48.260
There's a couple of protocols
that we gotta talk about that

454
00:23:48.260 --> 00:23:49.988
we use inside voice over IP.

455
00:23:49.988 --> 00:23:53.176
One of them is known as
the Session Initiation Protocol and

456
00:23:53.176 --> 00:23:55.640
the other one is known as H323.

457
00:23:55.640 --> 00:23:56.567
They both have different ports.

458
00:23:56.567 --> 00:24:01.880
And in fact SIP, the session initiation
protocol, which is responsible for

459
00:24:01.880 --> 00:24:05.930
communicating the parameters
of a communication.

460
00:24:05.930 --> 00:24:06.820
Boy, that's redundant.

461
00:24:06.820 --> 00:24:11.590
For defining the parameters of
a communication establishing it,

462
00:24:11.590 --> 00:24:12.410
maintaining it.

463
00:24:12.410 --> 00:24:14.980
Almost like transmission control
protocol is doing, right?

464
00:24:14.980 --> 00:24:17.000
And then breaking that down.

465
00:24:17.000 --> 00:24:19.268
Session initiation protocol
uses two ports, all right?

466
00:24:19.268 --> 00:24:22.569
50, 60 and
I don't have anything good for that one.

467
00:24:22.569 --> 00:24:23.120
>> [LAUGH]

468
00:24:23.120 --> 00:24:24.600
>> I mean it's just 5060.

469
00:24:24.600 --> 00:24:26.360
By the way that's not the two ports.

470
00:24:26.360 --> 00:24:29.566
50, 60 and then 50,
61 per session initiation protocol.

471
00:24:29.566 --> 00:24:34.158
The other one that we use in voice
over IP communications too is

472
00:24:34.158 --> 00:24:38.677
the H323 that uses port 1720,
again port 1720.

473
00:24:38.677 --> 00:24:43.200
All right,
Mile let me look through my list here.

474
00:24:43.200 --> 00:24:47.408
I think [CROSSTALK]
>> I see one there SMB.

475
00:24:47.408 --> 00:24:50.288
>> SMB, how can we forget our Windows

476
00:24:50.288 --> 00:24:52.580
communications, right?

477
00:24:52.580 --> 00:24:57.120
My goodness, so Windows communications,
when I need to make a connection

478
00:24:57.120 --> 00:25:00.230
to a shared resource within
a Windows environment.

479
00:25:00.230 --> 00:25:02.977
We're gonna do that over something known
as server message block, all right?

480
00:25:02.977 --> 00:25:08.431
And server message block,
I know they've got port 145 here.

481
00:25:08.431 --> 00:25:13.910
I believe it's got another port too,
port 139 as well, if I can't remember.

482
00:25:13.910 --> 00:25:18.646
But I know it's port 445 when it comes to
SMB, and I do want you to know that for

483
00:25:18.646 --> 00:25:19.300
the exam.

484
00:25:19.300 --> 00:25:23.611
Server message block again is
the way that you make that

485
00:25:23.611 --> 00:25:28.857
connection from say my machine into
whether it be a shared folder,

486
00:25:28.857 --> 00:25:33.090
whether it be a printer,
those other shares as well.

487
00:25:33.090 --> 00:25:35.360
Shared hard drive,
we talk about administrative shares.

488
00:25:35.360 --> 00:25:39.558
The way you connect to that is over
server message bot with port 445.

489
00:25:39.558 --> 00:25:42.150
I don't know why for
the life of me I'm thinking port 149.

490
00:25:42.150 --> 00:25:46.600
I think that's SMB over net BIOS if I
remember, but another protocol that you

491
00:25:46.600 --> 00:25:48.980
don't have to worry about for another
time that we'll definitely mention.

492
00:25:48.980 --> 00:25:50.912
But these are some [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

493
00:25:50.912 --> 00:25:52.626
>> Of the rules for communications,

494
00:25:52.626 --> 00:25:56.642
what we use them for, the service types if
you will as well as their port numbers,

495
00:25:56.642 --> 00:25:58.135
and if you can remember them.

496
00:25:58.135 --> 00:26:00.780
Should be doing good for
your Net plus exam.

497
00:26:00.780 --> 00:26:02.490
>> All right Wes, great look there.

498
00:26:02.490 --> 00:26:05.840
We thank you for that nice list of
all these different protocols, and

499
00:26:05.840 --> 00:26:09.410
associated port numbers that we need
to know for our exam, as well as taking

500
00:26:09.410 --> 00:26:13.060
a look at what the different protocols
are used for, and the protocol types.

501
00:26:13.060 --> 00:26:16.010
Remember, we talked about
connection-oriented protocols,

502
00:26:16.010 --> 00:26:17.970
versus connectionless protocols.

503
00:26:17.970 --> 00:26:19.120
So we thank you for that.

504
00:26:19.120 --> 00:26:21.390
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

505
00:26:21.390 --> 00:26:24.390
Signing off for ITPRoTV,
I've been your host Mike Roderick.

506
00:26:24.390 --> 00:26:25.110
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

507
00:26:25.110 --> 00:26:26.023
>> And we'll see you next time.

508
00:26:26.023 --> 00:26:33.742
[MUSIC]

509
00:26:33.742 --> 00:26:35.790
>> Thank you for watching ITPRoTV.

episodes.description: In this episode -- and Wes dive into the Open Systems Interconnection model \(OSI model\). They look at some of the applications, devices and protocols that operated within the different layers of the OSI model.
episodes.title: OSI Model
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.210
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:03.443
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.443 --> 00:00:06.059
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.059 --> 00:00:08.194
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.194 --> 00:00:11.526
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.
>> Hello,

6
00:00:11.526 --> 00:00:15.340
welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:15.340 --> 00:00:17.470
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and

8
00:00:17.470 --> 00:00:21.110
today we're doing our
Accelerated CompTIA Network+.

9
00:00:21.110 --> 00:00:23.820
And specifically in this episode
we're gonna be taking a close look at

10
00:00:23.820 --> 00:00:25.660
the OSI model.

11
00:00:25.660 --> 00:00:28.720
And here to guide us through
the different layers is Mr. Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:28.720 --> 00:00:30.340
Welcome, Wes.
>> Hey how are you doing, Mike?

13
00:00:30.340 --> 00:00:32.910
I don't know if we'll ever have a show
that doesn't have an acronym right

14
00:00:32.910 --> 00:00:33.591
in the title.

15
00:00:33.591 --> 00:00:35.482
[LAUGH]
>> I was thinking the same thing.

16
00:00:35.482 --> 00:00:39.047
So that's right, we are looking at
the open systems interconnection model.

17
00:00:39.047 --> 00:00:43.770
Remember that it is a seven layer
abstract computing architecture,

18
00:00:43.770 --> 00:00:48.770
if you will, that basically defines
how communications will travel

19
00:00:48.770 --> 00:00:53.400
from an application until finally making
their way out on the physical cable.

20
00:00:53.400 --> 00:00:55.650
Those electrical impulses we see.

21
00:00:55.650 --> 00:00:59.200
Whether we're using bounded media or
radiated energy and

22
00:00:59.200 --> 00:01:01.560
we need to know those individual layers.

23
00:01:01.560 --> 00:01:04.730
Remember it was actually
started back in I think,

24
00:01:04.730 --> 00:01:09.030
1984 by the International Organization
of Standardization, right?

25
00:01:09.030 --> 00:01:12.900
In those earlier days, keep in mind that
everybody was trying to do things their

26
00:01:12.900 --> 00:01:15.290
own way and they said, you know what?

27
00:01:15.290 --> 00:01:18.190
If everybody's doing something their own
way that means you're going to get vendor

28
00:01:18.190 --> 00:01:21.950
lock and there's going to be no
inner operability between these

29
00:01:21.950 --> 00:01:26.330
different networks and
local area networks if you will.

30
00:01:26.330 --> 00:01:28.390
So they came up with
a standardized approach.

31
00:01:28.390 --> 00:01:34.630
And we need to know a little bit about
each one of those seven abstract layers.

32
00:01:34.630 --> 00:01:36.440
I actually have a little diagram here and

33
00:01:36.440 --> 00:01:38.820
we can talk about each
one of these in general.

34
00:01:38.820 --> 00:01:42.720
When we talk about seven layers it really
depends on whether you're sending or

35
00:01:42.720 --> 00:01:46.890
receiving communication as to where you
start within what they call protocol

36
00:01:46.890 --> 00:01:47.900
stack, right.

37
00:01:47.900 --> 00:01:53.090
We'll talk in other episodes about
what's known as TCP/IP model as well,

38
00:01:53.090 --> 00:01:57.210
because it's also a layered model that
we really follow for the internet today.

39
00:01:57.210 --> 00:01:59.990
But understand that when
you hear protocols stack

40
00:01:59.990 --> 00:02:02.750
we're looking at the layers
of the OSI model.

41
00:02:02.750 --> 00:02:07.193
Now let's go ahead, we're gonna start from
the top layer and we'll work our way down

42
00:02:07.193 --> 00:02:10.315
to the floor, we'll work our
way down to the bottom layer.

43
00:02:10.315 --> 00:02:14.950
All right you'll hear me use these
terms interchangeably too so

44
00:02:14.950 --> 00:02:19.490
you'll have to keep up, keep in mind
that we all in the accelerated Net Plus.

45
00:02:19.490 --> 00:02:22.110
If you want more information
definitely go back and

46
00:02:22.110 --> 00:02:26.130
check out our full Network Plus episodes.

47
00:02:26.130 --> 00:02:29.240
So in the very first one we have
what's known as the application layer.

48
00:02:29.240 --> 00:02:31.710
That's Layer 7 of the OSI model.

49
00:02:31.710 --> 00:02:34.130
We then have the presentation layer,
Layer 6.

50
00:02:34.130 --> 00:02:37.890
We have the session layer, Layer 5.

51
00:02:37.890 --> 00:02:39.030
Transport layer is Layer 4.

52
00:02:39.030 --> 00:02:41.750
We have the network layer,
which is Layer 3.

53
00:02:41.750 --> 00:02:44.020
Data link layer, well, that's Layer 2.

54
00:02:44.020 --> 00:02:46.980
But it's actually broken
up into two sub-layers that

55
00:02:46.980 --> 00:02:48.500
we'll talk about here in a second.

56
00:02:48.500 --> 00:02:50.630
And then physical layer, Layer 1.

57
00:02:50.630 --> 00:02:53.470
All right so let's go ahead and
go back up to the top and

58
00:02:53.470 --> 00:02:56.540
let's talk about the very first
one here all the way at the top.

59
00:02:56.540 --> 00:02:58.440
Let's talk about
the application layer first.

60
00:02:58.440 --> 00:03:02.400
The application layer is really
what allows our applications and

61
00:03:02.400 --> 00:03:06.290
programs is the ability to even
have access to the network, right?

62
00:03:06.290 --> 00:03:10.330
We have a lot of different protocols,
now please understand there are tons of

63
00:03:10.330 --> 00:03:13.280
protocols, I just gave you
some as examples here.

64
00:03:13.280 --> 00:03:16.230
For instance,
we have email applications, right?

65
00:03:16.230 --> 00:03:17.540
We have email protocols.

66
00:03:17.540 --> 00:03:19.130
These sit at the application layer.

67
00:03:19.130 --> 00:03:22.500
We have things like file access protocols,
file transfer protocol.

68
00:03:22.500 --> 00:03:24.460
I just put FTP here.

69
00:03:24.460 --> 00:03:27.470
But network file system is
another one that would sit here.

70
00:03:27.470 --> 00:03:29.980
In our Windows machine, Samba,
or not Samba, excuse me,

71
00:03:29.980 --> 00:03:32.820
SMB would sit up here at
the application layer.

72
00:03:32.820 --> 00:03:36.520
And it's really the entry point
into the network communication.

73
00:03:36.520 --> 00:03:41.300
That's why we have things like DNS,
HTTP as well.

74
00:03:41.300 --> 00:03:42.920
Now, the application layer,

75
00:03:42.920 --> 00:03:47.160
once our data has access to the network,
now what we have to do is we have to start

76
00:03:47.160 --> 00:03:49.805
formatting it in a way that we
can place it on the network.

77
00:03:49.805 --> 00:03:52.160
And the network doesn't
have to worry about that,

78
00:03:52.160 --> 00:03:56.590
the network can worry about moving the
information from end point to end point.

79
00:03:56.590 --> 00:03:59.170
And, that's where you
sometimes might even hear,

80
00:03:59.170 --> 00:04:02.210
I've actually heard the presentation
layer before called the syntax layer.

81
00:04:02.210 --> 00:04:05.860
We don't usually call it that, but
they say syntax because what's it doing?

82
00:04:05.860 --> 00:04:10.440
It's formatting your information,
compressing your information data,

83
00:04:10.440 --> 00:04:11.720
encryption happens here.

84
00:04:11.720 --> 00:04:13.690
Again, so it's preparing that information.

85
00:04:13.690 --> 00:04:17.150
I think of it as like,
I need to send a letter in the mail.

86
00:04:17.150 --> 00:04:18.850
Well, I've got my letter, right?

87
00:04:18.850 --> 00:04:21.430
Think of the application layer,
I just wrote my letter.

88
00:04:21.430 --> 00:04:25.650
Well, I need to start getting it prepared
to put on the carrier's network, so

89
00:04:25.650 --> 00:04:27.040
I need an envelope, right?

90
00:04:27.040 --> 00:04:28.360
Then once I put it in an envelope,

91
00:04:28.360 --> 00:04:31.540
now I've got it formatted in
a way that here in the States

92
00:04:31.540 --> 00:04:35.670
our United States Postal Service is gonna
understand that's a snail mail letter.

93
00:04:35.670 --> 00:04:38.170
At least we understand what it is,
we don't know where it's going yet, but

94
00:04:38.170 --> 00:04:40.740
we do understand what it is.

95
00:04:40.740 --> 00:04:43.130
And, so that's Layer 6.

96
00:04:43.130 --> 00:04:48.030
Moving down the layers,
if we look at Layer 5, the session layer.

97
00:04:48.030 --> 00:04:53.010
Now, the session layer is responsible for
establishing the communication, right?

98
00:04:53.010 --> 00:04:56.810
Defining what are the parameters,
how are we going to communicate, right,

99
00:04:56.810 --> 00:04:58.324
between endpoints, right?

100
00:04:58.324 --> 00:05:02.240
Maintaining those communications and, one
I just kind of ran out of room here for

101
00:05:02.240 --> 00:05:06.040
is, actually terminating the
communication, once it's no longer needed.

102
00:05:06.040 --> 00:05:08.490
Now, I will tell you,

103
00:05:08.490 --> 00:05:12.020
notice that we have transmission
control protocol, a lower layer.

104
00:05:12.020 --> 00:05:15.270
Well, transmission control protocol
actually works on a couple of these layers

105
00:05:15.270 --> 00:05:18.720
when you look at it, because it's
a connection oriented service.

106
00:05:18.720 --> 00:05:22.180
If you remember from our ports and
protocols episode that we did,

107
00:05:22.180 --> 00:05:25.550
we talked about transmission control
protocol bringing that communication

108
00:05:25.550 --> 00:05:28.750
online establishing
a connection oriented service.

109
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:31.550
Maintaining that service and
then tearing it down.

110
00:05:31.550 --> 00:05:36.069
Well guess what, transmission control
protocol has it's functionality sitting at

111
00:05:36.069 --> 00:05:37.332
session layer as well.

112
00:05:37.332 --> 00:05:39.290
Kind of ran out of room,
didn't put it up there.

113
00:05:39.290 --> 00:05:42.680
[LAUGH] And
then as we move down the stack here,

114
00:05:42.680 --> 00:05:46.520
you'll see that Layer 4 is going to be
what's known as the transport layer.

115
00:05:46.520 --> 00:05:49.010
Now the transport layer, and
let me go ahead, and I'll tell you what,

116
00:05:49.010 --> 00:05:50.430
I'll stop right here.

117
00:05:50.430 --> 00:05:53.840
I want to look at the application
presentation and session layer.

118
00:05:53.840 --> 00:05:57.370
This is what's known as
the application functioning block.

119
00:05:57.370 --> 00:06:01.380
And what it's about is, it's really
about preparing your information to be

120
00:06:01.380 --> 00:06:03.290
placed onto the network, if you will.

121
00:06:03.290 --> 00:06:06.360
And if they ever ask you that on the exam,

122
00:06:06.360 --> 00:06:10.490
which is the application functional block,
I got a little trick for you.

123
00:06:10.490 --> 00:06:13.640
It's spelled right in the first letters,
right there,

124
00:06:13.640 --> 00:06:17.090
APS, if you can remember that,
application function block, APS,

125
00:06:17.090 --> 00:06:19.670
right there, kind of one of
those little tricks that you can

126
00:06:19.670 --> 00:06:22.110
kind of remember it on the exam.
>> Very

127
00:06:22.110 --> 00:06:24.640
handy.
>> But once we get to the transport down

128
00:06:24.640 --> 00:06:27.630
now we're talking about
the network functioning block.

129
00:06:27.630 --> 00:06:31.220
Because now we have the network
is going to be responsible for

130
00:06:31.220 --> 00:06:32.440
getting this communication.

131
00:06:32.440 --> 00:06:33.760
We have our envelope, right?

132
00:06:33.760 --> 00:06:36.710
It's ready, we know,
do we need delivery confirmation,

133
00:06:36.710 --> 00:06:39.590
do we need best effort delivery, right?

134
00:06:39.590 --> 00:06:42.580
Well that's where we're going to make
those selections at the transport layer.

135
00:06:42.580 --> 00:06:44.060
What kind of connection?

136
00:06:44.060 --> 00:06:47.330
Do we even need a connection or
is it service as well?

137
00:06:47.330 --> 00:06:51.130
So, understand that if it's a session
layer communication and using UDP,

138
00:06:51.130 --> 00:06:55.170
there might not be
a session establishment.

139
00:06:55.170 --> 00:06:56.680
Right?
So, just keep that in mind, too.

140
00:06:56.680 --> 00:07:00.390
So, at the transport layer, this is where
you're actually moving your information.

141
00:07:00.390 --> 00:07:03.910
You're choosing how you're gonna move
that information along the network.

142
00:07:03.910 --> 00:07:07.650
So transmission control
protocol sits here too.

143
00:07:07.650 --> 00:07:11.290
Both UDP and TCP, they move information.

144
00:07:11.290 --> 00:07:12.380
They do it a little bit different.

145
00:07:12.380 --> 00:07:15.780
If it's transmission control protocol,
understand that its doing segmenting and

146
00:07:15.780 --> 00:07:18.660
sequencing, like we talked
about in other episodes.

147
00:07:18.660 --> 00:07:22.110
It happens at the transport layer,
or Layer 4 of the OSI model.

148
00:07:23.600 --> 00:07:25.510
All right,
now we get down to the Networking layer.

149
00:07:25.510 --> 00:07:27.590
All right, and
this is everybody's fun layer too,

150
00:07:27.590 --> 00:07:29.100
especially when things go wrong, right?

151
00:07:29.100 --> 00:07:29.990
When things go wrong,

152
00:07:29.990 --> 00:07:32.220
it's gotta be the network's fault.
>> Yep, always.

153
00:07:32.220 --> 00:07:33.910
>> Layer 3, that's right.

154
00:07:33.910 --> 00:07:36.460
Layer 3 of the OSI model
network layer here.

155
00:07:36.460 --> 00:07:38.170
This is where we get things like IP.

156
00:07:38.170 --> 00:07:40.920
We've got our envelope, right?

157
00:07:40.920 --> 00:07:44.400
We've kind of determined, hey, do I want
a connection oriented service, right?

158
00:07:44.400 --> 00:07:46.560
Do I want deliver confirmation,
return, receipt?

159
00:07:46.560 --> 00:07:50.560
Or do I just want to put the snail mail in
the blue box and walk away from it, right?

160
00:07:50.560 --> 00:07:55.057
But whatever choice I make, I still got
to figure out where is it coming from and

161
00:07:55.057 --> 00:07:56.773
where is it going to, right?

162
00:07:56.773 --> 00:07:58.893
Well, and it's more important
as where it's going to,

163
00:07:58.893 --> 00:08:00.714
cuz that's the purpose of networking,
right?

164
00:08:00.714 --> 00:08:02.716
[LAUGH] Is to send a communication.

165
00:08:02.716 --> 00:08:06.232
But think about your letter, right?

166
00:08:06.232 --> 00:08:10.630
You have a mailing address and
you have a return address, right?

167
00:08:10.630 --> 00:08:13.150
So the source and
destination of this snail mail.

168
00:08:13.150 --> 00:08:13.920
Well, guess what?

169
00:08:13.920 --> 00:08:17.220
Here at the network layer, you have source
and destination of your communication.

170
00:08:17.220 --> 00:08:19.110
And what is doing that for us?

171
00:08:19.110 --> 00:08:21.200
IP, Internet protocol, right?

172
00:08:21.200 --> 00:08:24.170
We also have other things that operate
at this layer too, like for instance,

173
00:08:24.170 --> 00:08:25.410
some of our routing protocols.

the presentation layer information.

403
00:20:01.630 --> 00:20:04.350
And then it gets handed down
to the transport layer.

404
00:20:04.350 --> 00:20:05.120
And guess what.

405
00:20:05.120 --> 00:20:07.370
Yes the transport layer
adds its information.

406
00:20:07.370 --> 00:20:12.925
So you can see, this encapsulation process
is what we call going down the stack.

407
00:20:12.925 --> 00:20:17.400
Then finally down to the network layer,
when we hit the network layer this is

408
00:20:17.400 --> 00:20:20.510
where we're adding things like our source
and destination IP addresses and then

409
00:20:20.510 --> 00:20:25.830
finally down to the data link layer and
this is where we're looking and checking

410
00:20:25.830 --> 00:20:29.930
things like MAC addresses if you will,
this is where your frames are happening.

411
00:20:29.930 --> 00:20:32.550
Finally, we get down to
the physical layer, and

412
00:20:32.550 --> 00:20:34.860
this is where our binary ones and
zeros are, right.

413
00:20:34.860 --> 00:20:37.580
Our electrical impulses, our raw bits.

414
00:20:37.580 --> 00:20:40.270
Now when you are going down the stack,

415
00:20:40.270 --> 00:20:42.420
that means you're sending information,
all right?

416
00:20:42.420 --> 00:20:44.500
That means I'm sending
information to Mike's computer.

417
00:20:44.500 --> 00:20:49.420
My data has to be prepared so it'll
make its way out onto the medium, and

418
00:20:49.420 --> 00:20:51.540
make it's way to Mike's computer.

419
00:20:51.540 --> 00:20:55.110
Now once Mike's computer
receives that information,

420
00:20:55.110 --> 00:20:59.200
now he's gonna start processing
the information up the protocol stack.

421
00:20:59.200 --> 00:21:00.520
So you hear those terms, jargon.

422
00:21:00.520 --> 00:21:03.220
They say, down the protocol stack,
up the protocol stack.

423
00:21:03.220 --> 00:21:04.990
If I'm sending information,

424
00:21:04.990 --> 00:21:09.140
we're going down the protocol stack to the
encapsulation of process of adding all of

425
00:21:09.140 --> 00:21:13.610
the extra information to get your
communications over to the destination.

426
00:21:13.610 --> 00:21:18.110
Once it hits the destination, you're gonna
strip off that excess information or

427
00:21:18.110 --> 00:21:19.550
process it, if you will.

428
00:21:19.550 --> 00:21:24.600
Finally, we get back to the inside of
the wrapper and that's our raw data.

429
00:21:24.600 --> 00:21:27.390
So know a little bit about the OSI model.

430
00:21:27.390 --> 00:21:32.060
Know some of the devices that we've seen
that actually operate at these layers.

431
00:21:32.060 --> 00:21:35.890
Be prepared to know what protocols
operate at different layers too.

432
00:21:35.890 --> 00:21:38.000
Doesn't mean you have to
know all the protocols, but

433
00:21:38.000 --> 00:21:39.410
definitely know some common ones.

434
00:21:39.410 --> 00:21:41.080
Know things like IP.

435
00:21:41.080 --> 00:21:42.600
Know things that your routing protocols.

436
00:21:42.600 --> 00:21:45.610
Know that your routers operate at layer 3.

437
00:21:45.610 --> 00:21:49.150
Right know that ethernet operates at
layer two and the physical layer.

438
00:21:49.150 --> 00:21:51.090
Know that at layer two
things like switches.

439
00:21:51.090 --> 00:21:54.440
This is gonna be important information for
the network plus exam.

440
00:21:54.440 --> 00:21:56.210
Then it's also important information,

441
00:21:56.210 --> 00:22:00.010
too, as you'll see when we move
into our troubleshooting model.

442
00:22:00.010 --> 00:22:03.160
So you know, well, where's the issue line.

443
00:22:03.160 --> 00:22:05.520
Well, if Mike was to come to
me right now and say hey, Wes,

444
00:22:05.520 --> 00:22:08.220
we don't have communications,
I think it's a layer 3 issue.

445
00:22:08.220 --> 00:22:11.560
Well, he's telling me right away, I don't
know if it's the IP address that's wrong,

446
00:22:11.560 --> 00:22:14.850
I don't know if my our router's happening,
something's happening.

447
00:22:14.850 --> 00:22:17.470
Or he says, I think we've got
a physical layer problem.

448
00:22:17.470 --> 00:22:20.330
I know that what I need to do is I need
to go start checking cables, right?

449
00:22:20.330 --> 00:22:22.310
Cuz I know that cables operate
at the physical layer.

450
00:22:22.310 --> 00:22:24.620
So it's perfect for
troubleshooting as well.

451
00:22:24.620 --> 00:22:27.090
Don't think that it's all theory right?

452
00:22:27.090 --> 00:22:30.540
It's a lot of theory, mostly theory, but
you can also use that same theory and

453
00:22:30.540 --> 00:22:35.730
you're troubleshooting, when it comes
to trying to identify diagnose and

454
00:22:35.730 --> 00:22:38.580
then hopefully resolve the issues that
you might face within your network.

455
00:22:38.580 --> 00:22:43.970
The OSI model is very important not just
in a theory purpose you're going to be

456
00:22:43.970 --> 00:22:48.180
using it even in your networking careers.
>> Alright, great stuff there, Wes.

457
00:22:48.180 --> 00:22:50.440
Really good look at the OSI model,

458
00:22:50.440 --> 00:22:54.720
the different layers that make up that
OSI model, and what goes on at each one.

459
00:22:54.720 --> 00:22:56.670
As well as where some
of these devices work,

460
00:22:56.670 --> 00:22:59.310
another very important part of
Getting ready for this exam,

461
00:22:59.310 --> 00:23:03.310
understanding where those routers operate,
where those switches operate.

462
00:23:03.310 --> 00:23:08.720
And kinda breaking out that matryoshka,
I think, doll type situation where each

463
00:23:08.720 --> 00:23:12.990
layer is just wrapping or encapsulating
that previous layer's information.

464
00:23:12.990 --> 00:23:14.840
And then sending it across the wire and

465
00:23:14.840 --> 00:23:18.280
then breaking each one of those layers off
at the other end as it receives that data.

466
00:23:18.280 --> 00:23:20.720
So we appreciate that Wes, we thank you.

467
00:23:20.720 --> 00:23:24.380
And then hope everybody out there enjoyed
watching this one signing off for ITProTV,

468
00:23:24.380 --> 00:23:27.020
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

469
00:23:27.020 --> 00:23:29.509
>> And we'll see you next time.

470
00:23:29.509 --> 00:23:35.043

471

17

We're going be looking at things
like what happens when two

And some of the problems that

>> And maybe bring it down a more

acceptable level of, I wouldn't say risk,

23
00:01:00.390 --> 00:01:04.570
So let's go ahead and let's dive right
into, and one of the first things that I

24
00:01:04.570 --> 00:01:08.420
wanna do is probably start out with
the communication types that we have.

25
00:01:08.420 --> 00:01:11.720
Before we get into things like broadcast
domains, and collision domains,

26
00:01:11.720 --> 00:01:13.070
which, we'll get into in a second.

27
00:01:13.070 --> 00:01:15.390
Let's go ahead,
if we say a broadcast domain, well,

28
00:01:15.390 --> 00:01:17.000
what the heck is a broadcast?
>> [LAUGH]

29
00:01:17.000 --> 00:01:18.880
>> And why is it in a domain, right?

30
00:01:18.880 --> 00:01:21.970
So, let's go ahead, and
we'll define it there, we'll start there.

31
00:01:21.970 --> 00:01:25.940
Let's talk about three communication
types that we have in our networks and

32
00:01:25.940 --> 00:01:28.300
while there's a fourth one there,
it's not in the objectives.

33
00:01:28.300 --> 00:01:32.060
I do want to go ahead and just kinda
mention it cuz you'll see it in IPv6 and

34
00:01:32.060 --> 00:01:34.660
we'll talk more about IPv6

35
00:01:34.660 --> 00:01:37.370
One of the first communications that
we have, since I've already kinda let

36

the cat out of the bag,
we'll talk about broadcast communication.

37
00:01:40.510 --> 00:01:44.662
I've got a little diagram here, and when
we talk about a broadcast communication,

38
00:01:44.662 --> 00:01:48.050
I want you to understand it as
a one to all communication, right?

39
00:01:48.050 --> 00:01:51.050
I want you to think of this as like maybe
going down to the shopping mall and

40
00:01:51.050 --> 00:01:51.910

Standing in the middle of the food court

00:01:59.020 --> 00:02:02.590

44
00:02:02.590 --> 00:02:05.620
Well, that's the same thing that
happens inside of your networks when

45
00:02:05.620 --> 00:02:08.060
nodes send broadcast communications.

46
00:02:08.060 --> 00:02:10.760
It means they're sending,
as you'll learn in later episodes,

47
00:02:10.760 --> 00:02:13.900
to a specific address that says, hey,
I wanna send that communication.

48
00:02:13.900 --> 00:02:16.490
Because i want everybody
on the network to hear it.

49
00:02:16.490 --> 00:02:19.380
And it has its purpose
within our networks today.

50
00:02:19.380 --> 00:02:22.141
We'll go on and
we'll learn about things like ARP,

51
00:02:22.141 --> 00:02:25.770
and how ARP helps us to resolve
MAC addresses to IP addresses.

52
00:02:25.770 --> 00:02:31.790
And so it does have its utilizations
inside of our networks today.

53
00:02:31.790 --> 00:02:35.080
Now the next type of communication
that we have is probably

54
00:02:35.080 --> 00:02:37.010
the polar opposite of a broadcast, right?

55
00:02:37.010 --> 00:02:40.240
If we say a broadcast is a one to all,

56
00:02:40.240 --> 00:02:42.990
well a unicast is a one
to one communication.

57
00:02:42.990 --> 00:02:45.310
This is when you're
asking a specific device.

58
00:02:45.310 --> 00:02:48.130
You're not saying hey,
everybody, I wanna talk to you.

59
00:02:48.130 --> 00:02:49.930
You're saying hey Mike,
I just need to talk to you,

60
00:02:49.930 --> 00:02:51.630
I don't need to talk to
everybody else in the room.

61
00:02:51.630 --> 00:02:56.920
And again, it is a directed one to
one communication, and so know that.

62
00:02:56.920 --> 00:02:59.780
And so for instance,
if you're doing a file transfer, right?

63
00:02:59.780 --> 00:03:03.130
If you're doing a file transfer,

64
00:03:03.130 --> 00:03:07.240
And you're communicating just between
you and that file server, your node,

65
00:03:07.240 --> 00:03:10.850
if you will and that file server,
that is a unicast communication.

66
00:03:10.850 --> 00:03:14.090
So remember, one to all, one to one.

67
00:03:14.090 --> 00:03:17.370
But then there's another one out there and

00:03:17.370 --> 00:03:21.970
and I like to liken this one

69
00:03:21.970 --> 00:03:27.210
If you think about it,
they commonly say one to many, all right?

70
00:03:27.210 --> 00:03:30.690
To kind of differentiate it between

00:03:30.690 --> 00:03:35.140
I want you think of it instead of one to
many, one to a specific group, all right?

00:03:35.140 --> 00:03:36.730
Or one to a collection of nodes, right?

73
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:39.270
That's why they say many,
but it's really a group.

74
00:03:39.270 --> 00:03:41.360
If you're not in the group,
well guess what?

75
00:03:41.360 --> 00:03:42.320
You don't get the communication,

76
00:03:42.320 --> 00:03:44.570
and that's kind of like I said
with the pay-per-view event.

77
00:03:44.570 --> 00:03:48.210
If you think about it,
I remember when I was younger, me and

78
00:03:48.210 --> 00:03:50.385
my friends we used to love

00:03:50.385 --> 00:03:53.630
But we would all save up our money,
right, and

80
00:03:53.630 --> 00:03:56.800
we would get the one mom that could stand

00:03:56.800 --> 00:03:58.250
and we'd say, Okay, we got our money.

82
00:03:58.250 --> 00:04:00.740
Can you order the pay-per-view event,
right?

83
00:04:00.740 --> 00:04:05.950
And her house or that house would be
the one house within the neighborhood,

84
00:04:05.950 --> 00:04:09.970
well that we knew of that would be
getting that pay-per-view event right?

85
00:04:09.970 --> 00:04:14.900
Now from the cable provider side right,
that pay-per-view event is going

86
00:04:14.900 --> 00:04:18.750
to everybody that's in the group,
specifically the people who paid right?

87
00:04:18.750 --> 00:04:20.880
That's kind of like a multicast.

88
00:04:20.880 --> 00:04:24.340
A multicast is a one to a group,
one to a select few.

89
00:04:24.340 --> 00:04:27.220
You have to be in the group,
you receive the communications.

90
00:04:27.220 --> 00:04:31.440
You're not in the group, understand
you don't receive the transmission.

91
00:04:32.520 --> 00:04:34.510
There's another one that I want
to throw out there, because,

92
00:04:34.510 --> 00:04:36.470
again, it's not called
out in the objectives.

93
00:04:36.470 --> 00:04:40.350
But as we move in, at the time
of this recording we're in 2018,

94
00:04:40.350 --> 00:04:43.760
you're getting more and
more exposure to IPv6.

95
00:04:43.760 --> 00:04:46.620
I also want to call out another one and
that's called an anycast.

96
00:04:46.620 --> 00:04:50.320
All right, it's another communication type
not as popular as those three common ones

97
00:04:50.320 --> 00:04:55.110
but an anycast is a one to the best,
all right?

98
00:04:55.110 --> 00:04:57.690
Basically you can have more
than one destination but

99
00:04:57.690 --> 00:05:00.940
when your device is gonna figure out
where do I sent this information?

100
00:05:00.940 --> 00:05:02.380
I'm gonna use the best choice.

101
00:05:02.380 --> 00:05:04.380
We see that in things like DNS, right?

102
00:05:04.380 --> 00:05:07.650
As we talked in other episodes,
we talked about the DNS hierarchy.

103
00:05:07.650 --> 00:05:10.750
There's hundreds and hundreds of root
servers out there, root hint servers,

104
00:05:10.750 --> 00:05:14.480
where we start the name
resolution process off, right?

105
00:05:14.480 --> 00:05:18.350
Well, am I going to go to one that's
all the way around the world to China,

106
00:05:18.350 --> 00:05:21.990
or am I going to go to one that's sitting

107
00:05:21.990 --> 00:05:25.140
All right, it's one to the best, it
doesn't necessarily mean it's one to all,

108
00:05:25.140 --> 00:05:29.360
its not one to a select few,
it's one to whatever the best choice is.

109
00:05:29.360 --> 00:05:33.520
It's called an anycast, it's part of IPv6,

110
00:05:34.620 --> 00:05:37.730
Now that we understand what
the communication types are,

111
00:05:37.730 --> 00:05:41.226
that might make a little bit more sense

112
00:05:41.226 --> 00:05:45.490
like broadcast domains and

113
00:05:45.490 --> 00:05:48.728
In another episode, we talk about our
network topologies and one of the things

114
00:05:48.728 --> 00:05:51.734
that we mentioned in that episode,

115
00:05:51.734 --> 00:05:57.100
Remember that all your nodes are connected

116
00:05:57.100 --> 00:06:00.960
We have to understand, like we've
mentioned, is that when one node sends

117
00:06:00.960 --> 00:06:06.660
a communication, down that same shared

118
00:06:06.660 --> 00:06:09.600
Now here's the thing

00:06:09.600 --> 00:06:14.380

00:06:14.380 --> 00:06:18.460
Well two trains headed towards each other

00:06:18.460 --> 00:06:20.580
eventually what's gonna happen

122
00:06:20.580 --> 00:06:23.520
Well the same thing happens with
electrical collisions inside of

123
00:06:23.520 --> 00:06:24.740
your networks.

124
00:06:24.740 --> 00:06:27.840
All right,
that's what's known as a collision domain.

125
00:06:27.840 --> 00:06:31.580
When you have two nodes in the same shared
medium and they send communication at

126
00:06:31.580 --> 00:06:36.550
the same time, they're known as being
a part of the same collision domain.

127
00:06:37.670 --> 00:06:39.540
Unlike a broadcast domain.

00:06:39.540 --> 00:06:41.890
Remember the example of
a broadcast communication,

00:06:52.860 --> 00:06:54.690

00:06:54.690 --> 00:06:57.360
But when when we talk about
broadcast communications and

00:06:57.360 --> 00:07:01.960

the broadcast domain, all right?

Let me show you what I mean here,

When we plug computers into a hub,

00:07:19.610 --> 00:07:20.660
Why is that?

00:07:20.660 --> 00:07:24.278
Well, remember that if PC 1

00:07:24.278 --> 00:07:25.749

00:07:25.749 --> 00:07:28.550
Well, PC 2.
>> Anybody that's hooked up to that host

00:07:28.550 --> 00:07:29.461
>> PC 3, that's right.

00:07:29.461 --> 00:07:31.920
>> So is there a potential that PC 1, and

00:07:31.920 --> 00:07:34.610
let's just say numerically going
from the left to the right here,

00:07:34.610 --> 00:07:37.950
that PC 2 could send information
into the hub at the same time?

149
00:07:37.950 --> 00:07:39.660
Well there is a potential right?

150
00:07:39.660 --> 00:07:43.141
That's a collision domain,
because if one sends, they all hear,

00:07:43.141 --> 00:07:47.432
two send at the same time, there's gonna

The problem with that is, guess what?

616
00:31:30.780 --> 00:31:36.010
If I take a 9000 byte frame and I check
that integrity check on the back of it and

617
00:31:36.010 --> 00:31:39.390
it's bad, I'm not just
discarding 1500 bytes anymore.

618
00:31:39.390 --> 00:31:42.250
Like, I would be if it was just
in the normal standard MTU,

619
00:31:42.250 --> 00:31:44.800
now I have to throw away 9000 bytes.

620
00:31:44.800 --> 00:31:48.740
So just like we talk about,
in any computing there is give and takes.

621
00:31:48.740 --> 00:31:51.560
Yeah, if I leave it at 1500,
I'm sending less data, but

622
00:31:51.560 --> 00:31:55.250
I'm also throwing less data away
if the integrity's not maintained.

623
00:31:55.250 --> 00:31:57.040
You increase a jumbo bytes, yes,

624
00:31:57.040 --> 00:32:00.390
you do have the ability to
send 9000 bytes at a time.

625
00:32:00.390 --> 00:32:04.840
But if the frame checksum sequence is
calculated and the CRC value isn't good

626
00:32:04.840 --> 00:32:07.420
and it's discarded,
you're discarding a lot of information and

627
00:32:07.420 --> 00:32:09.670
we're gonna get those requests for
re-transmission.

628
00:32:09.670 --> 00:32:13.470
So, those are some of the network traffic
properties that you gotta be aware of for

629
00:32:13.470 --> 00:32:15.010
the Network+ exam.

630
00:32:15.010 --> 00:32:19.210
Keep in mind, if you wanna lot more
demonstrations and even some lab,

631
00:32:19.210 --> 00:32:23.360
I guess, demonstrations here,
check out the full Net+.

632
00:32:23.360 --> 00:32:25.730
We just wanna get you
there as fast as possible.

633
00:32:25.730 --> 00:32:26.350
>> Fantastic.

634
00:32:26.350 --> 00:32:27.460
All right, Wes, love it.

635
00:32:27.460 --> 00:32:31.480
Good look there at Network properties or
properties of our network traffic.

636
00:32:31.480 --> 00:32:32.500
We thank you for that.

637
00:32:32.500 --> 00:32:34.850
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

638
00:32:34.850 --> 00:32:37.660
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

639
00:32:37.660 --> 00:32:38.440
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

640
00:32:38.440 --> 00:32:39.500
>> And we'll see you next time.

641
00:32:39.500 --> 00:32:46.596
[MUSIC]

642
00:32:46.596 --> 00:32:48.870
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

>> That's right, we're gonna dive into

15
00:00:30.470 --> 00:00:33.160
the routing technologies,
like Zach has talked about.

16
00:00:33.160 --> 00:00:36.670
If you have been following along

remember the OSI model we talked

18

We're gonna be talking about some

19
00:00:43.440 --> 00:00:44.720
where the routers sit.

20
00:00:44.720 --> 00:00:49.650
And we're gonna talk about things like
routing protocols here, and basically,

21
00:00:49.650 --> 00:00:52.540
some of the concepts of
how routers make decisions

22
00:00:52.540 --> 00:00:56.302
about where to send their information.
>> Now when we're talking about routing,

23
00:00:56.302 --> 00:01:00.380
are we talking moving data and
across and in between networks,

24
00:01:00.380 --> 00:01:02.450
is that what we're talking about?
>> That's exactly what it is,

25
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:03.630
that's exactly what it is.

26
00:01:03.630 --> 00:01:05.790
My computer sends information, and

27
00:01:05.790 --> 00:01:10.000
it doesn't really know how to
get information across networks.

28
00:01:10.000 --> 00:01:12.350
We say source and
destination of a communication.

29
00:01:12.350 --> 00:01:15.360
Typically, it's two endpoints and
in the middle of those two endpoints,

30
00:01:15.360 --> 00:01:17.630
we have redistribution points.

31
00:01:17.630 --> 00:01:21.357
Down there at layer one we have things
like hubs, that we've talked about,

32
00:01:21.357 --> 00:01:23.116
that are really just dumb devices.

33
00:01:23.116 --> 00:01:25.065
They're really nothing
more than like a repeater.

34
00:01:25.065 --> 00:01:29.715
They just broadcast information
out of all of their ports, but

35
00:01:29.715 --> 00:01:31.977
they don't really make
any logical decisions.

36
00:01:31.977 --> 00:01:34.147
Switches on the other hand,
now we move up the stack.

37
00:01:34.147 --> 00:01:36.287
Up the protocol stack,
the OSI model, if you will.

38
00:01:36.287 --> 00:01:39.547
And now we're talking about things
like switches that can start to

39
00:01:39.547 --> 00:01:43.587
forward information between nodes
within a local area network.

40
00:01:43.587 --> 00:01:44.237
But remember,

41
00:01:44.237 --> 00:01:48.890
a switch is only aware of the devices
that are directly connected to its ports.

42
00:01:48.890 --> 00:01:52.760
Even if it's another switch, it still has
to have a port to port connection in order

43
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:55.510
to send information along the wire.

44
00:01:55.510 --> 00:01:56.570
Wire just being figurative for

45
00:01:56.570 --> 00:01:57.560
the network.
>> Right.

46
00:01:57.560 --> 00:01:59.575
>> But then when we move up into layer

47
00:01:59.575 --> 00:02:02.780
three, now that's where we get
things like logical addressing.

48
00:02:02.780 --> 00:02:06.171
Like IP addresses, we start looking
at things like network IDs.

49
00:02:06.171 --> 00:02:09.820
And routers are intelligent,
routers don't need to be connected.

50
00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:14.390
They do not need to be connected to
a network to send that information.

51
00:02:14.390 --> 00:02:17.320
To make a decision,
to look at a routing table and

52
00:02:17.320 --> 00:02:21.180
say hey I've got this database
of networks that I'm aware of.

53
00:02:21.180 --> 00:02:22.700
Or paths, if you will,

54
00:02:22.700 --> 00:02:27.410
these routes that I'm aware of to send
information to a certain direction.

55
00:02:27.410 --> 00:02:30.440
And based on what I find in that table

56
00:02:30.440 --> 00:02:34.485
is gonna dictate where I'm gonna send this
information to get to the remote network.

57
00:02:34.485 --> 00:02:37.853
In fact, it's really routing
that allows us to communicate,

58
00:02:37.853 --> 00:02:40.023
you and I, right now, to communicate.

59
00:02:40.023 --> 00:02:41.943
And I know its a one-way communication,
if you will,

60
00:02:41.943 --> 00:02:43.965
because you're not really
communicating back with me.

61
00:02:43.965 --> 00:02:47.145
But if you're watching this, and
obviously you have an internet connection,

62
00:02:47.145 --> 00:02:49.170
well it's the routers that
allow that to happen.

63
00:02:49.170 --> 00:02:53.650
So, these are the work horses when
it comes to WAN communications,

64
00:02:53.650 --> 00:02:55.623
across different networks.

65
00:02:55.623 --> 00:02:57.706
And it really doesn't have
to be a WAN communication,

66
00:02:57.706 --> 00:02:59.180
it can be an autonomous system.

67
00:02:59.180 --> 00:03:03.686
Autonomous system, if you will,
is just a network, if you will,

68
00:03:03.686 --> 00:03:07.718
that is under the control of
a single administrative body.

69
00:03:07.718 --> 00:03:12.390
And it typically adheres to
a certain routing protocol.

70
00:03:12.390 --> 00:03:16.463
And one of the things to keep in mind is,
that's really what the internet is,

71
00:03:16.463 --> 00:03:18.533
it's a bunch of local area networks all

72
00:03:18.533 --> 00:03:19.710
holding hands
>> Mm-hm.

73
00:03:19.710 --> 00:03:21.578
>> And it's the routers that allow them to

74
00:03:21.578 --> 00:03:24.930
talk to one another, and essentially
allows you to watch this video.

75
00:03:24.930 --> 00:03:29.675
So let's go ahead and
let's dive into routing technologies.

76
00:03:29.675 --> 00:03:34.164
Now, remember one of the first
things that we want to talk about

77
00:03:34.164 --> 00:03:39.025
is that routing protocols if you will,
they define how routers share information.

78
00:03:39.025 --> 00:03:42.585
I told you that they look at a database,
it's called a routing table.

79
00:03:42.585 --> 00:03:45.605
Well how that table gets
built with the routes or

80
00:03:45.605 --> 00:03:49.225
the paths that its gonna send
the information out of it's various

81
00:03:49.225 --> 00:03:52.370
interfaces, really can happen
in a few different ways.

82
00:03:52.370 --> 00:03:55.990
And it depends on the protocol
that you're using that defines

83
00:03:55.990 --> 00:03:57.860
how that table gets built.

84
00:03:57.860 --> 00:04:02.199
Routing protocols, if you will, they can
be called a couple of different things.

85
00:04:02.199 --> 00:04:05.820
In fact, I got a little diagram here,
let's kinda check this out.

86
00:04:05.820 --> 00:04:10.410
Because we have a couple of different
types of routing protocols generically.

87
00:04:10.410 --> 00:04:11.560
We've got quite a few different,

88
00:04:11.560 --> 00:04:15.430
I guess, kinds of routing protocols,
flavors, if you will.

89
00:04:15.430 --> 00:04:17.850
But we primarily have two different types.

90
00:04:17.850 --> 00:04:22.950
And what I mean by that is
we have routing protocols

91
00:04:22.950 --> 00:04:27.810
that route information within an
autonomous system or within your networks.

92
00:04:27.810 --> 00:04:31.688
And then we have routing protocols
that actually allow the networks to

93
00:04:31.688 --> 00:04:32.551
communicate.

94
00:04:32.551 --> 00:04:35.330
So you can have a heavily
routed environment.

95
00:04:35.330 --> 00:04:37.190
If you have a large
enterprise environment,

96
00:04:37.190 --> 00:04:40.030
you're gonna probably
have multiple subnets.

97
00:04:40.030 --> 00:04:43.815
Remember what routers do, they route
traffic based on the logical identifier

98
00:04:43.815 --> 00:04:46.063
known as IP between
those different subnets.

99
00:04:46.063 --> 00:04:49.480
Well the same thing goes,
if you will, across the internet.

100
00:04:49.480 --> 00:04:53.880
But in an internal network you could
have many, many different networks,

101
00:04:53.880 --> 00:04:56.000
many subnets.

102
00:04:56.000 --> 00:05:01.400
And those protocols that route traffic
with inside your autonomous systems,

103
00:05:01.400 --> 00:05:05.410
with inside of those routed environments
are what are known as interior

104
00:05:05.410 --> 00:05:08.230
gateway protocols, IGPs if you will.

105
00:05:08.230 --> 00:05:11.250
And we'll talk about the different
various IGPs because

106
00:05:11.250 --> 00:05:13.048
again they have different flavors.

107
00:05:13.048 --> 00:05:16.470
They all kinda fall under that
umbrella term, if you will,

108
00:05:16.470 --> 00:05:19.120
called an interior gateway protocol.

109
00:05:19.120 --> 00:05:24.920
Now if I need to send information
between these networks across like a WAN

110
00:05:24.920 --> 00:05:28.110
linked to different networks, then what we
use is something a little bit different.

111
00:05:28.110 --> 00:05:31.650
We use what's known as
an exterior gateway protocol.

112
00:05:31.650 --> 00:05:36.280
Notice that, what this does is this
allows the two different networks again

113
00:05:36.280 --> 00:05:40.070
to communicate when,
let's say Zack has one autonomous system.

114
00:05:40.070 --> 00:05:46.110
He works for company, and they have all of
their routers, routing information inside.

115
00:05:46.110 --> 00:05:48.290
Those are the interior gateway protocols.

116
00:05:48.290 --> 00:05:53.350
I have an autonomous system, again just a
collection of networks or single network.

117
00:05:53.350 --> 00:05:56.170
Could be a single network, a lot of
times they're really big, for instance,

118
00:05:56.170 --> 00:05:57.490
Apple has an autonomous system.

119
00:05:57.490 --> 00:06:01.440
And I can almost guarantee you there's
not just a single network within Apple's

120
00:06:01.440 --> 00:06:03.070
massive infrastructure.

121
00:06:03.070 --> 00:06:08.260
So within Apple's infrastructure, they
have their interior gateway protocols.

122
00:06:08.260 --> 00:06:13.260
Let's say my company wants to talk
over the internet, through or

123
00:06:13.260 --> 00:06:15.440
to, Zach's network.

124
00:06:15.440 --> 00:06:18.460
Well now what we're using is
exterior gateway protocols.

125
00:06:18.460 --> 00:06:23.210
Again, the exterior gateway protocols
route traffic between autonomous systems.

126
00:06:23.210 --> 00:06:28.060
Now the other thing to keep in mind
is that interior gateway protocols,

127
00:06:28.060 --> 00:06:32.670
they don't share information
with other autonomous systems.

128
00:06:32.670 --> 00:06:36.050
They keep that information
to themselves internally,

129
00:06:36.050 --> 00:06:38.590
and hence why they're
called interior gateway.

130
00:06:38.590 --> 00:06:43.076
Think of your router, if I'm gonna
route traffic to another network,

131
00:06:43.076 --> 00:06:48.410
to another company's network, I'm going
to use exterior gateway protocol.

132
00:06:48.410 --> 00:06:53.440
Inside of my routed environment I'm
gonna use interior gateway protocols

133
00:06:53.440 --> 00:06:58.350
that are only gonna communicate between
those routers within the interior,

134
00:06:58.350 --> 00:07:00.250
the other side of the gateway,
if you will.

135
00:07:00.250 --> 00:07:04.890
If I need to communicate with
Zach's network, my internal or

136
00:07:04.890 --> 00:07:06.480
interior gateway routers,

137
00:07:06.480 --> 00:07:10.970
they are not going to communicate their
routing information to Zach's network.

138
00:07:10.970 --> 00:07:13.250
It's a different administrative body.

139
00:07:13.250 --> 00:07:16.430
If we need to communicate between us,

140
00:07:16.430 --> 00:07:19.310
we're gonna use the exterior
gateway protocol.

141
00:07:19.310 --> 00:07:23.010
So understand basically that
that's kinda the basics of what

142
00:07:23.010 --> 00:07:25.460
the protocols are doing.

143
00:07:25.460 --> 00:07:30.120
All right, so let's go ahead and
let's define routes as well.

144
00:07:30.120 --> 00:07:32.050
Because we gotta kinda talk about routes.

145
00:07:32.050 --> 00:07:36.969
Now, there's a couple of different
ways that you can obtain routes.

146
00:07:36.969 --> 00:07:41.310
Now, routes can either be dynamic,
or they could be static.

147
00:07:42.410 --> 00:07:47.490
Now, if we talk about dynamic routes,

148
00:07:47.490 --> 00:07:50.810
that's where those interior
gateway protocols come in handy.

149
00:07:50.810 --> 00:07:54.440
Because what happens is the routers
communicate with one another.

150
00:07:54.440 --> 00:07:56.905
They share typology information.

151
00:07:56.905 --> 00:08:01.644
And every router must be consistent
with sharing that typology information.

152
00:08:01.644 --> 00:08:02.745
Those are dynamic routes.

153
00:08:02.745 --> 00:08:06.510
Cuz it means, let's say now
Zach's a router and I'm a router.

154
00:08:06.510 --> 00:08:07.588
We're gonna put your routing hat on.

155
00:08:07.588 --> 00:08:09.870
We'll put our routing hats on right?

156
00:08:09.870 --> 00:08:13.420
And I learn of a route, or
Zach as a router learns of a route, right?

157
00:08:13.420 --> 00:08:14.930
Zach's gonna come over and
he's gonna say, hey,

158
00:08:14.930 --> 00:08:18.490
Wes, I know a route to
get to this network.

159
00:08:18.490 --> 00:08:21.660
And I'm going to say, well, Zach,
thanks for the information,

160
00:08:21.660 --> 00:08:23.930
but I already got that route.

161
00:08:23.930 --> 00:08:24.850
But wait a second.

162
00:08:25.950 --> 00:08:28.580
Zach, I'm looking at your information,
you got a better way to get there.

163
00:08:28.580 --> 00:08:32.090
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
purge that route out of my database,

164
00:08:32.090 --> 00:08:33.190
my routing table.

165
00:08:33.190 --> 00:08:36.743
And I'm gonna accept that route
that you have found there, Zach,

166
00:08:36.743 --> 00:08:39.923
that is a better choice to get
to that destination network.

167
00:08:39.923 --> 00:08:43.480
And that's how we've dynamically
building up the routing table.

168
00:08:43.480 --> 00:08:45.139
>> So dynamic means flexibility,

169
00:08:45.139 --> 00:08:46.785
doesn't it?
>> It really does, and

170
00:08:46.785 --> 00:08:47.801
that's a good thing.

171
00:08:47.801 --> 00:08:51.081
So hold to that flexibility cuz we gonna
come right back to that cuz we're come

172
00:08:51.081 --> 00:08:53.604
right back to that cuz we gotta
differentiate it with static

173
00:08:53.604 --> 00:08:54.720
routes as well.

174
00:08:54.720 --> 00:08:58.570
Now, static routes are those
routes that are set manually

175
00:08:58.570 --> 00:09:00.500
by the administrator, all right?

176
00:09:00.500 --> 00:09:03.310
And what that says is, Zach, I only have,

177
00:09:03.310 --> 00:09:05.310
let's say,
one route going into this network.

178
00:09:05.310 --> 00:09:07.780
I really don't need to communicate
with you on how to get there.

179
00:09:07.780 --> 00:09:10.760
I'm the only one connected
to that network.

180
00:09:10.760 --> 00:09:14.538
So there's no reason to waste
things like raw processing power,

181
00:09:14.538 --> 00:09:17.240
if you will, or the communications.

182
00:09:17.240 --> 00:09:20.910
Because when a router needs to make a
decision, it's gonna use some of its CPU,

183
00:09:20.910 --> 00:09:22.980
it's gonna use some of its memory.

184
00:09:22.980 --> 00:09:25.410
And when there is communications
between the routers,

185
00:09:25.410 --> 00:09:30.160
updating things like routing tables,
that takes processing power, right?

186
00:09:30.160 --> 00:09:34.760
But there's no reason to say if I'm
only connected to a single network with

187
00:09:34.760 --> 00:09:37.130
one link, there's no reason
to waste that power, right?

188
00:09:37.130 --> 00:09:40.020
What I can do is I can define
a static route if there's

189
00:09:40.020 --> 00:09:42.120
only one route into that network.

190
00:09:42.120 --> 00:09:45.490
Now, let's go back to flexibility,
all right?

191
00:09:45.490 --> 00:09:50.410
The problem, the benefit of the static
route is the fact that you eliminate

192
00:09:50.410 --> 00:09:54.300
the necessity to calculate a routing
table because what you do when you define

193
00:09:54.300 --> 00:09:58.270
a static route is you're saying router,
I don't care what the routing table is,

194
00:09:58.270 --> 00:10:00.302
this is the route you're going to use,
all right?

195
00:10:00.302 --> 00:10:01.720
And that has its benefits.

196
00:10:01.720 --> 00:10:02.960
But here's the problem.

197
00:10:02.960 --> 00:10:08.080
If that route fails, all right,
since it isn't dynamic, I'm not going

198
00:10:08.080 --> 00:10:12.650
to turn around and ask Zack, well, I don't
know how to get to that network, Zach.

199
00:10:12.650 --> 00:10:16.360
I know I told you to hush before,
and I don't need your advice, but

200
00:10:16.360 --> 00:10:17.770
I'm not going to reach out and
ask for them.

201
00:10:17.770 --> 00:10:21.580
Statically defined routes, we don't
dynamically build the routing tables,

202
00:10:21.580 --> 00:10:25.310
which means it's good for processing
