425
00:23:15.860 --> 00:23:19.231
Network address translation, very
basically, it's a mingling of the packets.

426
00:23:19.231 --> 00:23:23.326
It allows you to use a private
IP address behind your gateway,

427
00:23:23.326 --> 00:23:27.670
your gateway router, and
what the gateway router does.

428
00:23:27.670 --> 00:23:31.170
Let's go ahead and
we'll take a look here, all right.

429
00:23:31.170 --> 00:23:34.484
So notice that a packet has
come into the router, right?

430
00:23:34.484 --> 00:23:37.468
And the router says,
that's a private IP address,

431
00:23:37.468 --> 00:23:40.270
I can't route that out to the internet,
right?

432
00:23:40.270 --> 00:23:44.518
So what it's gonna do is it's gonna
take its public IP address, and

433
00:23:44.518 --> 00:23:48.327
it's going to put that in the IP
header of that information.

434
00:23:48.327 --> 00:23:50.246
And then it's gonna take,

435
00:23:50.246 --> 00:23:56.180
it'll remove essentially the private IP
address replacing its public IP address.

436
00:23:56.180 --> 00:23:57.354
And now it's routable.

437
00:23:57.354 --> 00:24:00.316
Now we can send that information
across the internet.

438
00:24:00.316 --> 00:24:04.556
And when the information comes back in,
it'll have the public IP address.

439
00:24:04.556 --> 00:24:07.279
And also a port number.

440
00:24:07.279 --> 00:24:11.121
And this is where we get into something
not only network address translation but

441
00:24:11.121 --> 00:24:14.161
there's also something known as
port address translation and

442
00:24:14.161 --> 00:24:16.700
it can keep track of
the different communications.

443
00:24:16.700 --> 00:24:17.950
Like, well where's this going?

444
00:24:17.950 --> 00:24:21.900
Remember the dynamic ports we
talk about in other episodes?

445
00:24:21.900 --> 00:24:24.250
Well, you could see that high level
port and that's assign to it and

446
00:24:24.250 --> 00:24:26.730
say, well okay,
I see my Public IP Address, but

447
00:24:26.730 --> 00:24:30.160
I also see a port here,
I know what computer that goes to.

448
00:24:30.160 --> 00:24:34.910
And what it does is it
essentially removes that

449
00:24:34.910 --> 00:24:39.930
public IP address returns
the private IP address.

450
00:24:39.930 --> 00:24:43.180
And then if it's using port address
translation, it also knows the port,

451
00:24:43.180 --> 00:24:47.210
it says, okay, I see the port,
let me go ahead and

452
00:24:47.210 --> 00:24:49.570
forward this to the appropriate computer.

453
00:24:49.570 --> 00:24:52.680
So that's a little bit about
network address translation.

454
00:24:52.680 --> 00:24:54.430
And, just keep in mind.

455
00:24:54.430 --> 00:24:57.820
It's essentially just a mingling of
the packet in front of the IP header.

456
00:24:57.820 --> 00:25:01.230
And it's the replacing of the private
IP address with a public IP address so

457
00:25:01.230 --> 00:25:03.700
now that it can be routed
across the internet.

458
00:25:03.700 --> 00:25:07.740
It has a database that it maintains
of where that address came from so

459
00:25:07.740 --> 00:25:09.550
it knows to switch it back.

460
00:25:09.550 --> 00:25:11.590
It's doing port address translation,

461
00:25:11.590 --> 00:25:13.870
then it can also pay attention
to those high level ports.

462
00:25:13.870 --> 00:25:16.710
And when the information comes
back in other router it says

463
00:25:16.710 --> 00:25:19.730
I see that high level port goes to this
computer as part of that communication.

464
00:25:19.730 --> 00:25:23.970
Let me go ahead and strip up the public IP
address, return the private IP address and

465
00:25:23.970 --> 00:25:26.780
based on that port,
I know where to send that communication.

466
00:25:28.200 --> 00:25:31.080
All right, I know we're running
a little bit short on time.

467
00:25:31.080 --> 00:25:35.270
Here the last thing that I would like to
talk about just briefly is what is known

468
00:25:35.270 --> 00:25:37.430
as port forwarding.

469
00:25:37.430 --> 00:25:41.460
When we talk about port forwarding, this
is based on those port numbers, right?

470
00:25:41.460 --> 00:25:46.550
Sometimes, when you need to send
a specific type of traffic,

471
00:25:46.550 --> 00:25:50.390
based on an application or something,
to an individual node within your network.

472
00:25:50.390 --> 00:25:53.110
Wow, how do we do that, right?

473
00:25:53.110 --> 00:25:54.630
Well, we do that with port forwarding.

474
00:25:54.630 --> 00:25:57.530
And one of the ways that we do this a lot

475
00:25:57.530 --> 00:26:02.400

remote desktop protocol, RDP, right?

476
00:26:02.400 --> 00:26:06.310
When I need to go make a connection
over a public network back in to my home

477
00:26:06.310 --> 00:26:07.060
network, right.

478
00:26:07.060 --> 00:26:11.560
I'm going to be using RDP in
a Windows environment, right?

479
00:26:11.560 --> 00:26:13.610
Well that uses port 3389.

480
00:26:13.610 --> 00:26:16.080
When it hits my router,
and it sees port 3389,

481
00:26:16.080 --> 00:26:20.560
how does it know to send it to that one
computer that I want to remote into,

482
00:26:20.560 --> 00:26:22.740
if I have 1000,
1500 computers on my network?

483
00:26:22.740 --> 00:26:24.990
Well, it doesn't, so
it wouldn't know what to do with it.

484
00:26:24.990 --> 00:26:28.280
But if I put a port forwarding rule for

485
00:26:28.280 --> 00:26:32.740
port 3389 with the IP address so
the computer that I wanna talk to that

486
00:26:32.740 --> 00:26:35.910
when the router receives the information
it says, I see port 3389.

487
00:26:35.910 --> 00:26:38.360
Let me look at my port forwarding rules.

488
00:26:38.360 --> 00:26:43.780
Okay, I see that goes to 192.168.1.10,
arbitrary IP number.

489
00:26:43.780 --> 00:26:47.300
Lemme go ahead and send that communication
right to the specific computer, right?

490
00:26:47.300 --> 00:26:49.860
Port forwarding, it's a way that you can

491
00:26:49.860 --> 00:26:53.930
forward information to a specific
endpoint within your networks

492
00:26:53.930 --> 00:26:58.790
based on that port information that it
finds within the data packet, if you will.

493

These are some of the routing
technologies that we hope

>> Hey Zach, thanks for

11

In fact, we've got traditional types

and traffic that can't really

We could slow FTP down a little

18

Now, we've got to ensure that we're using

19

that maintains the integrity,

20
00:01:10.762 --> 00:01:14.330
We wanna make sure that that data

But we could slow, well,

24
00:01:22.910 --> 00:01:27.330
But one of the things that we don't wanna

25
00:01:27.330 --> 00:01:28.350
communications, right?

26
00:01:28.350 --> 00:01:33.271
When you have things like SIP phones,
H, what is it, 323,

27
00:01:33.271 --> 00:01:38.290
you have traffic like your
video conferencing traffic.

28
00:01:38.290 --> 00:01:42.700
See, that traffic, it can handle
a moderate amount of things like packet

29
00:01:42.700 --> 00:01:47.150
loss, but what it really doesn't
tolerate real well is a delay,

30
00:01:47.150 --> 00:01:49.410
it needs a very timely arrival, right.

31
00:01:49.410 --> 00:01:53.920
FTP, on the other hand,
we don't really want packet loss, cuz

32
00:01:53.920 --> 00:01:58.760
that would corrupt the information, but
it can handle a moderate amount of delay.

33
00:01:58.760 --> 00:01:59.948
And if you look at your network,

34
00:01:59.948 --> 00:02:02.243
your network only has a certain
amount of bandwidth, right.

35
00:02:02.243 --> 00:02:07.202
It doesn't matter how big or how small
the network is, the pipeline is so

36
00:02:07.202 --> 00:02:12.260
big, and we've got to find a way In
which we can prioritize, if you will.

37
00:02:12.260 --> 00:02:15.483
This type of traffic, well,
we can implement a little bit of delay, so

38
00:02:15.483 --> 00:02:17.980
we don't have to give it all

39
00:02:17.980 --> 00:02:18.840
And this type of traffic,

40
00:02:18.840 --> 00:02:21.646
we gotta make sure that we give
it a high priority, right?

41
00:02:21.646 --> 00:02:25.830
We prioritize it in the fact that it's
gonna get to the endpoint with less delay,

42
00:02:25.830 --> 00:02:27.540
or very little delay, right.

43
00:02:27.540 --> 00:02:32.042
So that's some of the things that we're
gonna talk about inside of this episode,

44
00:02:32.042 --> 00:02:36.152
is some of the technologies that we have
out there that they utilize in these

45
00:02:36.152 --> 00:02:37.211
modern networks.

46
00:02:37.211 --> 00:02:42.138
In order to guarantee that certain types
of traffic get the amount of resources

47
00:02:42.138 --> 00:02:47.080
within our networks that they need, so
let's go ahead and kinda define that.

48
00:02:47.080 --> 00:02:51.100
Now there's layer two ways that
we can do this, right, and

49
00:02:51.100 --> 00:02:53.390
there's also layer three ways, all right?

50
00:02:53.390 --> 00:02:56.380
Now, in layer two implementations,

51
00:02:56.380 --> 00:03:00.270
we do this a little bit
different than layer three.

52
00:03:00.270 --> 00:03:04.117
But ultimately, whether you're
talking about the data link layer, or

53
00:03:04.117 --> 00:03:07.343
you're talking about layer three,
the networking layer.

54
00:03:07.343 --> 00:03:12.023
It's really about inserting a little
bit of information into a certain field

55
00:03:12.023 --> 00:03:15.767
within the data packet or within,
if we are talking about IP or

56
00:03:15.767 --> 00:03:19.229
we're talking about layer three,
or within the frame.

57
00:03:19.229 --> 00:03:23.250
That will allow these connectivity
devices to receive that information,

58
00:03:23.250 --> 00:03:27.288
inspect those fields, and inspect
that little bit of extra information.

59
00:03:27.288 --> 00:03:31.492
And make a determination based on that
information as to whether it's high

60
00:03:31.492 --> 00:03:34.561
priority, medium priority,
maybe low priority, or

61
00:03:34.561 --> 00:03:38.110
maybe we just don't care,
best effort, right?

62
00:03:38.110 --> 00:03:40.110
So that's some of the things
that we need to look at.

63
00:03:40.110 --> 00:03:42.899
So let's go ahead and
start with the layer two information, or

64
00:03:42.899 --> 00:03:44.118
the layer two techniques.

65
00:03:44.118 --> 00:03:48.222
And when we talk about that,
we really kinda have to break down where

66
00:03:48.222 --> 00:03:52.620
this information resides, so
you can kind of see what's going on here.

67
00:03:52.620 --> 00:03:56.675
So let's go ahead and dive right into
what an Ethernet frame looks like.

68
00:03:56.675 --> 00:04:00.780
I've actually got just a small little
basic diagram here, there's nothing really

69
00:04:00.780 --> 00:04:07.230
fancy about this, that describes what an
Ethernet frame will look like, all right.

70
00:04:07.230 --> 00:04:10.780
When we look at a frame, it consists of
what's known as a preamble, all right.

71
00:04:10.780 --> 00:04:14.850
And a preamble, if you will,
it's just out in front of the frame,

72
00:04:14.850 --> 00:04:19.139
that allows your clocks within
your devices, right, the receiver,

73
00:04:19.139 --> 00:04:21.850
to be able to synchronize communications.

74
00:04:21.850 --> 00:04:25.790
Time's very important, right, so we need
to be able to synchronize information, and

75
00:04:25.790 --> 00:04:27.920
this is what that allows us to do.

76
00:04:27.920 --> 00:04:30.390
The next portion of this is
what's known as a start of frame,

77
00:04:30.390 --> 00:04:33.620
or sometimes called a start
of frame delimiter.

78
00:04:33.620 --> 00:04:37.190
And what that is is an 8-bit field,
and it marks the end of the preamble.

79
00:04:37.190 --> 00:04:41.020
And it says hey, your Ethernet frame
is gonna start right after me, right?

80
00:04:41.020 --> 00:04:45.246
So it's kind of like that, again,
delimiter between what the preamble is,

81
00:04:45.246 --> 00:04:49.486
and the actual fact that we've got,
now, data is going to start after that.

82
00:04:49.486 --> 00:04:53.150
Then the next thing we have is
the source and destination MAC address.

83
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:56.560
Remember that when switches receive the
information at layer two there, they're

84
00:04:56.560 --> 00:05:00.895
gonna inspect the MAC address to figure
out, which ports do I forward this to?

85
00:05:00.895 --> 00:05:04.915
I received it on port, let's say 20, let
me look at the destination MAC address.

86
00:05:04.915 --> 00:05:08.115
Okay, I see that MAC address,
let me look at my MAC table and

87
00:05:08.115 --> 00:05:12.278
find out what port that that computer or
destination node is attached to, and

88
00:05:12.278 --> 00:05:14.471
then that's the port I'll send it out.

89
00:05:14.471 --> 00:05:19.610
Then we have what's known as the ether
type, sometimes called the length as well.

90
00:05:19.610 --> 00:05:23.931
And what that does is, it just
indicates what protocol essentially is

91
00:05:23.931 --> 00:05:26.860
encapsulated in the payload for the frame.

92
00:05:26.860 --> 00:05:29.950
And it can also sometimes be
used to denote the length.

93
00:05:29.950 --> 00:05:32.460
So you might hear it called ether type,
you might hear it called length, but

94
00:05:32.460 --> 00:05:35.950
it let's you know what is the length
of the frame sometimes as well.

95
00:05:37.240 --> 00:05:42.362
Well, if you can't tell what the data is,
that's actually your payload, right.

96
00:05:42.362 --> 00:05:47.760
That's the information that we
need to move in between the nodes.

97
00:05:47.760 --> 00:05:52.530
The last portion of this, and well,
there might be padding, if it's needed.

98
00:05:52.530 --> 00:05:53.810
That's an optional thing,

99
00:05:53.810 --> 00:05:57.020
doesn't necessarily need to be there,
so if needed.

100
00:05:57.020 --> 00:05:59.710
And then the last portion is a checksum,
all right?

101
00:05:59.710 --> 00:06:03.960
That's what's known as the frame
checksum sequence, if you will.

102
00:06:03.960 --> 00:06:09.420
Now, that's just a 32-bit value,
it's a CRC 32, cyclic redundancy check.

103
00:06:09.420 --> 00:06:15.100
And remember that as far as performance of
our switches go, remember that the most

104
00:06:15.100 --> 00:06:18.939
common switching technique today is
what's known as store and forward, right?

105
00:06:20.080 --> 00:06:26.100
What the devices do is, they receive
the whole entire frame, they inspect

106
00:06:26.100 --> 00:06:31.350
the frame checksum sequence, or that CRC,
cyclic redundancy check, 32-bit value.

107
00:06:31.350 --> 00:06:35.810
And that tells us, well,
has that frame maintained its integrity?

108
00:06:35.810 --> 00:06:37.530
We're gonna store it, receive it,

109
00:06:37.530 --> 00:06:41.230
get the frame checksum sequence,
verify the integrity of the frame.

110
00:06:41.230 --> 00:06:46.130
If the frame has maintained its integrity,
we send it to the destination MAC address.

111
00:06:46.130 --> 00:06:50.082
If it hasn't, we discard it, and there's
gonna be a callout for a retransmission,.

112
00:06:50.082 --> 00:06:54.960
All right, now,
that's a basic ethernet frame, all right.

113
00:06:54.960 --> 00:07:00.158
Now, in other episodes, we've talked
about things like VLANs, right, and

114
00:07:00.158 --> 00:07:05.297
VLANs use what's known as 802.1Q,
that's the VLAN tagging portion.

115
00:07:05.297 --> 00:07:07.808
All right, now what that means is,

116
00:07:07.808 --> 00:07:12.350
we're gonna insert a little bit
of extra information, right?

117
00:07:12.350 --> 00:07:15.792
So what does that look like, well,
that kinda looks like this right here.

118
00:07:15.792 --> 00:07:22.290
So as we can see, when we compare a normal
untagged Ethernet frame with our 802.1Q.

119
00:07:22.290 --> 00:07:26.478
You can see, and my head's kinda covering
this up, that we add a little bit

120
00:07:26.478 --> 00:07:30.756
of information here, right, and
that's that VLAN tagging unit, right.

121
00:07:30.756 --> 00:07:35.310
Now, the VLAN tagging unit
is actually broke down into

122
00:07:35.310 --> 00:07:38.260
individual portions as well.

123
00:07:38.260 --> 00:07:42.520
And I wanna kinda talk about this, because
this is how we define a priority of

124
00:07:42.520 --> 00:07:44.490
traffic here at the switching level,
right?

125
00:07:44.490 --> 00:07:46.770
The layer two information, if you will,

126
00:07:46.770 --> 00:07:49.900
because it's a little bit different
when we talk about layer three or IP.

127
00:07:49.900 --> 00:07:55.088
Inside of that 802.1Q VLAN tag,
you have a couple fields,

128
00:07:55.088 --> 00:07:58.363
well, four different fields, right?

129
00:07:58.363 --> 00:08:01.637
You have what's known as a tag type,
all right, and

130
00:08:01.637 --> 00:08:06.639
the tag type just identifies the frame
as being Well, tag or untagged, right?

131
00:08:06.639 --> 00:08:09.360
And, we also have a priority.

132
00:08:09.360 --> 00:08:14.077
Now this is where we start to
talk about guaranteeing different

133
00:08:14.077 --> 00:08:18.177
levels of resources based
on it's priority, right?

00:20:58.260 --> 00:20:59.070
All right?

364
00:20:59.070 --> 00:21:03.040
And if the bandwidth is there, then
we're not really worried about it, but

365
00:21:03.040 --> 00:21:07.090
what we're going to do is gonna
reserve a portion of the bandwidth for

366
00:21:07.090 --> 00:21:12.210
that high priority device, all right,
that's called a reservation.

367
00:21:12.210 --> 00:21:15.350
Now, you can do an on-demand reservation,

368
00:21:15.350 --> 00:21:18.160
which means when it needs it,
it grabs it, all right?

369
00:21:18.160 --> 00:21:20.160
And when it doesn't need it,
it releases it back,

370
00:21:20.160 --> 00:21:23.710
those resources back over to the network.

371
00:21:23.710 --> 00:21:27.320
Or you could do more like
a static reservation that says,

372
00:21:27.320 --> 00:21:30.090
I don't care if that device needs it or
not.

373
00:21:30.090 --> 00:21:33.260
You're gonna reserve that bandwidth for
that device.

374
00:21:33.260 --> 00:21:34.980
Now, that could be good, it could be bad,

375
00:21:34.980 --> 00:21:37.110
it depends on the priority of the device,
right?

376
00:21:37.110 --> 00:21:39.960
It could be bad because what you're doing
is you're taking that resource away and

377
00:21:39.960 --> 00:21:42.960
you're giving it to a device that might
not need it at the time where other

378
00:21:42.960 --> 00:21:44.420
devices might need it.

379
00:21:44.420 --> 00:21:48.060
All right, but you're guaranteeing that
device has access to the bandwidth it

380
00:21:48.060 --> 00:21:49.920
needs when it needs it.

381
00:21:49.920 --> 00:21:52.930
All right, so two different ways.

382
00:21:52.930 --> 00:21:53.890
All right.

383
00:21:53.890 --> 00:21:58.220
Last thing that I wanna mention
is what is known as, again,

384
00:21:58.220 --> 00:22:01.980
it's more bandwidth manipulation,

385

386
00:22:08.060 --> 00:22:09.200
Let me show you here.

387
00:22:09.200 --> 00:22:11.720
Rate limiting,
think of it as an outbound, right?

00:22:11.720 --> 00:22:15.570
We've got a server that we're going

389
00:22:15.570 --> 00:22:18.490
Well we can set a threshold that says,

390
00:22:18.490 --> 00:22:23.100
this is the rate at which you can
make the requests, all right?

391
00:22:23.100 --> 00:22:28.040
Now, throttling says,
what happens if you hit that rate limit.

392
00:22:28.040 --> 00:22:32.705
Well, we're gonna slow you down,
all right.

393
00:22:32.705 --> 00:22:37.000
Now, there is something to understand
in rate limiting, what we're gonna do

394
00:22:37.000 --> 00:22:41.390
is we could reject information, right,
you could throw and discard information.

395
00:22:41.390 --> 00:22:45.260
Throttling just says hey,
let's just slow the amount of information

396
00:22:45.260 --> 00:22:50.030
that is going in or out of that
interface down to the acceptable level.

00:22:50.030 --> 00:22:52.740
You might see this is we're a big

00:22:52.740 --> 00:22:56.541

00:03:16.050 --> 00:03:19.190

Why is that?

Because your operating systems,

00:05:54.880 --> 00:05:56.800

00:05:56.800 --> 00:06:01.440
And it'll say okay, I notice I have one,

Well that means, IPv6 is an eight-block

00:06:11.380 --> 00:06:15.500

00:06:15.500 --> 00:06:16.690

Right, in IPv4, we say it's comprised

00:06:28.556 --> 00:06:33.272

00:06:33.272 --> 00:06:33.990

And then uniquely identifying node on

00:06:38.442 --> 00:06:40.110

00:06:40.110 --> 00:06:44.432
Well guess what, you also have

00:06:49.520 --> 00:06:55.939
Because when an IPv6 address is

When we say slash notation,

00:07:22.180 --> 00:07:26.420

00:07:31.900 --> 00:07:36.180
nice clean, right down the middle,

00:07:38.530 --> 00:07:43.570

One of the things than

a computer that is assigned

00:25:31.810 --> 00:25:34.150

00:25:34.150 --> 00:25:37.790
The Extended User Interface 64.

431

00:25:43.760 --> 00:25:48.420
That layer two address, and

00:25:48.420 --> 00:25:52.550
Remember our Mac address is a 48

00:25:52.550 --> 00:25:54.790
Six bytes long, half of the bytes,

00:26:00.330 --> 00:26:03.600
The last bytes identify
uniquely the network adapter

00:26:03.600 --> 00:26:05.350
within that manufacturer, right?

Those are the 48 bits.

Well they said,

00:26:09.690 --> 00:26:15.330
You know what, if we just go ahead and

00:26:16.330 --> 00:26:20.780
More importantly, FF, FE,

00:26:20.780 --> 00:26:25.150
if we divide the OUI in half, or

00:26:25.150 --> 00:26:28.830
And we've got the OUI, and we've got
the NIC, or the network interface card,

444
00:26:28.830 --> 00:26:33.930
the unique identifier for that and

445
00:26:33.930 --> 00:26:36.630
well, what 16 plus 48, 64.

00:26:36.630 --> 00:26:44.260
That'll be a way that the computer itself

00:26:45.350 --> 00:26:49.088

00:26:49.088 --> 00:26:55.415

a dynamically assigned network

Not network ID, the interface
ID becomes the last 64 bits and

00:27:06.730 --> 00:27:10.110

Now, so, one of the things that

In your network,

which means allow the DHCP server to hand

Or you can go with what's

It means you're gonna
